cleaned_text: Feasibility of a mindfulness- and relaxation-based mHealth intervention for cancer patients Thesis (cumulative thesis) presented to the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences of the University of Zurich for the degree of Doctor of Philosophy by Michael Jan Mikolasek Accepted in the fall semester 2021 on the recommendation of the doctoral committee: Prof. Dr. Ulrike Ehlert (main supervisor) PD Dr. Jürgen Barth Zurich, 2021ABSTRACT Cancer - a potentially life-threatening disease - is highly prevalent worldwide. Furthermore, quality of life is often impaired in cancer patients, for instance due to uncertainty about the progression of the disease or side effects from cancer treatment. Therefore, supportive psychosocial interventions are recommended to increase cancer patients' quality of life. Research shows that a variety of intervention techniques, such as counseling, stress management, relaxatio n and meditation can have beneficial effects on cancer patients' quality of life. Access to such interventions, however, can be limited, for instance due to a lack of treatment providers, impaired mobility of patients or lack of awareness of such interventions. To overcome such barriers to the access, the use of mobile health (mHealth) interventions has been recommended. mHealth interventions use mobile devices such as smartphones to deliver an intervention. Due to a large and continuously growing number of smartphone users, mHealth interventions can potentially reach a large number of patients. However, compared to research investigating more traditional face- to-face interventions, research on mHealth interventions is sparse. To bridge this gap, the aim of this thesis was to evaluate the feasibility of a mindfulness- and relaxation-based app interventions for cancer patients. We first conducted a systematic review where we summarized results from mindfulness- and relaxation-based interventions that were delivered through modern technologies such as the internet and aimed at patients with medical conditions. Second, we conducted a mindfulness- and relaxation-based app study for cancer patients. The study was guided by the RE-AIM evaluation framework, which assesses the following evaluations dimensions: Reach, effectiveness, adoption, implementation, and maintenance. We collected patient reported outcomes as well as data on app usage over the course of 20 weeks. Additionally, we conducted semi-structured interviews with patients and health professionals. Our results showed that a substantial number of patients regularly used the app over the course of 20 weeks. Patients' and health professionals' feedback in general was favorable and we received helpful feedback regarding possible improvements. Furthermore, our analyses revealed that over the course of the 20-week mHealth intervention, anxiety, distress, fatigue, sleep disturbance, quality of life, and mindfulness improved significantly. However, since our study did not have a control group, the effectiveness of the intervention needs to be tested in a future randomized controlled trial. II LIST OF ABBREVIATIONS CBT Cognitive behavioral therapy EORTC QLQ-C30 European Organization for Research and Treatment of Cancer Quality of Life Questionnaire Core 30 FACT-G Functional Assesment of Cancer Therapy -General HADS Hospital Anxiety Depression Scale MBCT Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy MBSR Mindfulness based stress reduction NEO- NEO 5-Factor Inventory PMR Progressive Muscle Relaxation PROMIS outcomes measurement information system RCT Randomized controlled trial RE-AIM Reach, Effectiveness, Adoption, Implementation, Maintenance RTC Resistance to Change WHO World Health Organization 1 INTRODUCTION Cancer is highly prevalent worldwide with an estimated 18.1 million new diagnoses in 2018 (Bray et al., 2018). In Switzerland, there are an estimated 42 '500 new cancer cases and 17'000 cancer death s per year (Krebsliga, 2021). A cancer diagnosis and its treatment can lead to a variety of physical and mental problems with a negative impact on quality of life. Cancer patients have an elevated risk for depression, oftentimes experience high distress due to the uncertainty of their prognosis and usually suffer from various physical health problems due to the cancer treatment (Krebber et al., 2014; Mehnert et al., 2018; Mitchell et al., 2011; Quinn, Gonçalves, Sehovic, Bowman, & Reed, 2015). These mental and physical health problems can also affect recovery and the adherence to cancer treatment (DiMatteo, Lepper, & Croghan, 2000; Van Cleave, Egleston, & McCorkle, 2011). Consequently, a variety of treatments have been suggested to increase cancer patients ' quality of life. Since the appearance of psycho- oncology in 1977 (Holland, 2002) a variety of psychosocial interventions have been suggested to support cancer patients and many of these interventions are effective in increasing cancer patients ' quality of life and well-being. However, not all distressed cancer patients seek help in form of psychosocial interventions. Additionally, the adherence of cancer patients to psychosocial interventions, which are usually delivered by health professionals, is often limited (Brebach, Sharpe, Costa, Rhodes, & Butow, 2016). Therefore, there has also been an increasing interest in developing self-care interventions for cancer patients (Dodd & Miaskowski, 2000; McCorkle et al., 2011). One possible way to deliver self-care interventions is through e-and mHealth interventions, which is the use of web or mobile device applications (Gunther Eysenbach, 2001; Heerden, Tomlinson, & Swartz, Jadad, 2005). e- and mHealth interventions are promising due to a variety of characteristic. Oftentimes such interventions provide a low-threshold access, since a growing number of people have access to the internet and own a mobile device such as a smartphone (Luxton, McCann, Bush, Mishkind, & Reger, 2011; Rowland, Fitzgerald, Holme, Powell, & McGregor, 2020). Therefore, an increasingly large number of people can access e- and mHealth interventions. Additionally, technological advances in the last couple of years allow for more sophisticated interventions using e- or mHealth interventions (Paglialonga, Patel, Pinto, Mugambi, & Keshavjee, 2019) . However, since these technological advances are rather recent, e- and especially mHealth studies are not as numerous as studies investigating standard treatments such as face- to-face therapy (Ali, Chew, & Yap, 2016; Marcolino et al., 2018). 2 Therefore, the aim of this thesis is to evaluate the feasibility of a mindfulness and relaxation mHealth intervention for cancer patients. First, we summarized the findings of mindfulness- and relaxation-based eHealth intervention for medical conditions in a systematic review. In a subsequent study, we evaluated the feasibility of a mindfulness and relaxation research app for cancer patients according to the RE-AIM evaluation framework (Glasgow, Vogt, & Boles, 1999). This framework assesses five dimensions, namely Reach (i.e. number of individuals participating in a intervention), Effectiveness or Efficacy (i.e. impact of an intervention on relevant outcomes), Adoption (i.e. number of settings and intervention agents who are willing to adopt an intervention), Implementation (i.e. extend to which an intervention is delivered as intended), and Maintenance (i.e. extend to which an intervention is sustained over time) (Glasgow et al., 1999). 3 A. THEORETICAL BACKGROUND 1. Epidemiology and treatment of cancer Cancer is highly prevalent worldwide: in 2018 it was estimated that there were 18.1 million new cancer diagnoses (Bray et al., 2018). The five most common cancers are lung cancer with 2.094 million new cases worldwide in 2018, followed by breast cancer (2.089 million cases), colorectal cancer (1.850 million cases), prostate cancer (1.276 million cases) , and non-melanoma skin cancer (1.042 million cases) (International Agency for Research on Cancer, 2018b). An estimated 9.6 million people worldwide died of cancer in 2018, making it the second leading cause of death globally (World Health Organization, 2018). The most common causes of cancer death in 2018 were lung cancer (1.761 million estimated deaths), colorectal cancer (880.729 estimated deaths), stomach cancer (782.685 estimated deaths), liver cancer (781.631 estimated deaths), and breast cancer (626679 estimated deaths) (International Agency for Research on Cancer, 2018a). In Switzerland, there are an estimated 42'500 new cancer cases per year (Krebsliga, 2021). The most common treatment of cancer is surgery, radiation therapy, chemotherapy, immunotherapy, targeted therapy, hormone therapy, stem cell transplant (National Cancer Institute, 2015). Since these treatments are highly invasive and targeting only cancer cells is difficult, treatments also negatively affect the overall health of a patient. The cancer diagnosis and cancer treatment can therefore lead to a variety of physica l and psychological problems such as fatigue and anxiety, which is described in more detail in the next chapter. The high prevalence and the far-reaching consequences of a cancer diagnosis and its treatment are also recognized by institutions like the Swiss Cancer League, which provides information and counseling regarding various aspects of cancer related issues and cancer treatment. The Swiss Cancer League furthermore supports research in four different areas, namely basic, clinical, psychosocial, and epidemiological research. This project was conducted within the domain of psychosocial research. 4 2. The impact of cancer on quality of life 2.1 Quality of life in cancer patients Quality of life is often defined as a multi-dimensional construct, consisting of physical, mental, social, and spiritual aspects of well-being (Ferrell & Down, 1997; McDonough, Eliott, Neuhaus, Reid, & Butow, 2019). In cancer patients, many aspects of well-being are affected, leading to an overall diminished quality of life. In some cases, this impairment can be long- lasting, despite a successful cancer treatment (Ander et al., 2016; Hopman & Rijken, 2015; Koch, Jansen, Williams, Jackson, Beeken, Steptoe, & Wardle, 2016; Wu & Harden, 2015). For instance, cancer survivors - usually defined as cancer patients still living five years after a cancer diagnosis (Feuerstein, 2007; Foster, Wright, Hill, Hopkinson, & Roffe, 2009) - may face various symptoms such as pain, fatigue, gastro-intestinal problems or depressive symptoms long after a completed treatment (Brearley et al., 2011; Harrington, Hansen, Moskowitz, Todd, & Feuerstein, 2010). Furthermore, cancer is not just affecting the diagnosed patient, it can also have a negative impact on the quality of life of the patients' partners Klitzing, 2015). Cancer patients' diminished quality of life can have additional negative consequences. For instance, poor quality of life in cancer patients is associated with reduced adherence to recommended lifestyle behavior changes such as physical activity or smoking cessation (Blanchard, Courneya, Stein, & American Cancer Society's, 2008). Moreover, lower levels of quality of life can also have a negative impact on cancer patients' adher ence to medical treatments (DiMatteo et al., 2000). Preliminary research also indicates that quality of life in cancer patients may have an impact on survivorship (Kypriotakis, Vidrine, Francis, & Rose, 2016). Regarding health care, cancer patients with reduced quality of life can cause higher healthcare costs, since they require more care (Mausbach, Yeung, Bos, & Irwin, 2018). These issues indicate that cancer, in and of itself a severe and potentially life-threatening illness, can have far-reaching negative effects. The subsequent sections elaborate in more detail on aspects of physical, mental and social well-being in cancer patients, which can be associated with reduced quality of life. 2.1.1 Impact of cancer on physical well-being 5 Cancer treatment can lead to a variety of physical symptoms, which can negatively impact patients' well -being and therefore goes along with reduced quality of life(Quinn et al., 2015). Symptoms in cancer patient s which are associated with cancer treatment include for instance diarrhea (Klee et al., 1999), nausea and vomiting (Rhodes, Johnson, & McDaniel, 1995). Furthermore, cancer patients often report sleep disturbances (Coles et al., 2018). Problems associated with sleep disturbances are fatigue, leg restlessness, insomnia, and excessive sleepiness (J. R. Davidson, MacLean, Brundage, & Schulze, 2002). A large number of cancer patients also suffer from pain during or after cancer treatment (Andersen & Kehlet, 2011; Gartner et al., 2009) , which has also an impact on patients' well -being. Another common side effect of chemotherapies is alopecia (loss of hair), which is ranked by patients to be amongst the most troublesome side effects of the chemotherapy (Lemieux, Maunsell, & Provencher, 2008). In addition, several cancer types are associated with weight loss, while in other cancers weight gain is typical (Helms, O'Hea, & Corso, 2008). In some cases of breast cancer, surgery (lumpectomy or mastectomy) is necessary, which leads to a visible change of the patients' body appearance (Helms et al., 2008). These changes in a patients' physical appearance can also have a negative impact on the patients' well -being (Kalaitzi et al., 2007). Oral complications, which is common in head and neck cancer patients treated with radiotherapy, can also negatively affect quality of life (Epstein, Robertson, Emerton, Phillips, & Stevenson-Moore, 2001). Physical well-being can also be affected after cancer treatment. For instance, undesirable physical symptoms such as infertility (Schover, 2005; Ussher & Perz, 2019) weight gain dysfunction (Ewer, Swain, Cardinale, Fadol, & Suter, 2011) can occur after treatment. Furthermore, cancer-related fatigue can also persist for severa l month after a successful cancer treatment (Berger, Gerber, & Mayer, 2012; Bower, 2005). Research indicates that cancer patients with more physical symptoms or side effects are at greater risk of being distressed (Jim, Andrykowski, Munster, & Jacobsen, 2007; Walker et al., 2017). Therefore, physical symptoms in cancer patients can have a negative impact on mental well-being as well, which will be outlined in more detail in the next section. 2.1.2 Impact of cancer on mental well-being Many cancer patients report elevated levels of psychological distress (Mehnert et al., 2018). Various factors, such cancer stage and type of cancer diagnosis (Subramaniam et al., 6 2018; Zabora, BrintzenhofeSzoc, Curbow, Hooker, & Piantadosi, 2001) can have an impact on the prevalence of distress and therefore impact quality of life. Furthermore, research indicates that the diagnosed cancer type can also make a difference on patients' level of distress. In a study by Bergerot and colleagues, patients diagnosed with a rare cancer report poorer quality of life compared with patients diagnosed with a more common cancer (Bergerot et al., 2018). In addition, patients with multiple primary cancers have an even more reduced quality of life compared to patients with a single cancer location (Belcher, Hausmann, Cohen, Donovan, & Schlenk, 2017). The National Comprehensive Cancer Network recommends screening all cancer patients regularly for distress (National Comprehensive Cancer Network, 2020). This recommendation is warranted since studies have shown that distress is often not recognized by oncological staff (Jacobsen et al., 2005). Therefore, distress in cancer patients is oftentimes untreated, which can have various negative impacts (Carlson et al., 2004). Elevated levels of distress in cancer patients are for instance associated with poor health status, low adherence to treatment recommendations, and increased pain and fatigue (Mehnert et al., 2018; Okuyama, Jones, Ricklefs, & Tran, 2015). Distress in cancer patients does not only occur shortly after diagnosis or during the treatment, but can also be present post-treatment (Henselmans et al., 2010). A study by Hoffman and colleagues (Hoffman, McCarthy, Recklitis, & Ng, 2009) showed that long-term cancer survivors are at increased risk for psychological distress. A simple and popular way of measuring distress is the use of the distress thermometer, which was developed by Roth and colleagues Roth et al. (1998). The distress thermometer is a visual analogue scale, ranging from 0 (no distress) to 10 (extreme distress) (Roth et al., 1998). This distress thermometer has been used in a large variety of oncological patient groups and shows good predictive validity (Jacobsen et al., 2005; Mitchell, 2007). Research indicates that a score of 5 or higher is of clinical relevance (Jacobsen et al., 2005). More specifically, cancer patients can be affected by anxiety and depression. In comparison to the general population, cancer patients have elevated levels of depression and anxiety (Mitchell et al., 2011; Mosher, Winger, Given, Helft, & O'Neil, 2016). A meta-analysis show ed that estimates of depression in cancer patients differ, with percentages ranging from 8% to 24 % (Krebber et al., 2014). Several factors like type of instrument used to measure depression, cancer type and treatment phase can have an impact on the prevalence of depression in cancer patients (Krebber et al., 2014). Cancer patients have elevated prevalence rates of depression compared to the general population, where prevalence of about 7% has been 7 reported (Mausbach & Irwin, 2017). A study by Mausbach and Irwin also showed that depression in cancer patients goes along with more annual visits of healthcare providers that were not mental health experts (Mausbach & Irwin, 2017). Furthermore, patients with advanced cancer have a higher risk for developing a major depressive episode compared to the general population (Meyer, Fletcher, Prigerson, Braun, & Maciejewski, 2015). Major depression in cancer patients can adversely affect treatment adherence, quality of life, and survival in cancer patients (Meyer et al., 2015; Pinquart & Duberstein, 2010). Cancer patients have also an increased risk of committing suicide (Ahn et al., 2015). A study reported that high-risk cancer patients for committing suicide are often older (over 55 years) white male patients (Massetti, Holland, Jack, Ragan, & Lunsford, 2018). Another study found that depression, pain, and medical comorbidities can be additional suicide risk factors in cancer patients (Aboumrad, Shiner, Riblet, Mills, & Watts, 2018). Yet another common mental disorder in cancer patients is adjustment disorder (Geue et al., 2018) . Regarding mental health in different care settings, a meta-analysis (Mitchell et al., 2011) reported that the prevalence of depression, anxiety, or adjustment disorder d id not differ in palliative vs. non-palliative setting. For cancer survivors, a meta-analysis showed that anxiety is higher in long-term cancer survivors compared to the general population, whereas depression has a similar prevalence rate (Mitchell, Ferguson, Gill, Paul, & Symonds, 2013). A further common psychological factor affecting mental well-being and subsequently quality of life in cancer survivors is the fear of a recurring cancer (Hartl et al., 2003; Reed et al., 2018; Simonelli, Siegel, & Duffy, 2017; Vickberg, 2003). Although a consensual definition is lacking (Simard et al., 2013), a typical characteristic of fear of recurrence is the fear or worry that the cancer will reoccur in the same or another body part (Vickberg, 2003). In 2013, three systematic reviews reported that fear of recurrence is a widespread problematic and one of the most prevalent unmet needs of cancer survivors, even five or more years after treatment (Crist & Grunfeld, 2013; Koch, Jansen, Brenner, & Arndt, 2013; Simard et al., 2013). The majority of cancer patients report low to moderate levels of fear of recurrence through survivorship and the data so far suggests that fear of recurrence remains stable over time (Simard et al., 2013). Therefore, it is not surprising that cancer survivors with a clinical level of fear of recurrence are more likely to consult health ca re providers and to take psychotropic drugs (Champagne, Ivers, & Savard, 2018). 2.1.3 Impact of cancer on social well-being 8 Cancer can also have an impact on a patients ' social life. A variety of social problems, such as problems with health and welfare services, financial burden, employment, and relationship can occur after a cancer diagnosis , which can negatively impact patients' social well-being (Fenn et al., 2014; Wright, Kiely, Lynch, Cull, & Selby, 2002). Sexuality is in many cases also altered after a cancer diagnosis, which can lead to a reduced quality of life in both cancer patients and their partners (Tierney, 2008). Furthermore, research also shows that partners of cancer patients can experience fear of recurrence as well (Cohee et al., 2017), which can additionally burden a relationship. However, a functioning relationship can be of importance, since a supportive spouse can buffer the stressful impact of cancer (Regan et al., 2015). Furthermore, young adults with cancer oftentimes face problems with employment, education, or financial stability, which can have a negative impact on patients' well -being a nd subsequently result in reduced quality of life (Warner et al., 2016). 9 3. Treatments to improve cancer patients ' quality of life The previous chapters highlight ed that cancer patients oftentimes face reduced well- being. Since factors influencing patients ' well-being, such as distress, anxiety, and depression are common in cancer patients and are associated with reduced quality of life, treatment adherence and socio-economic consequences , dealing with these factors has become an additional goal in the treatment of cancer patients. One of the first efforts to tackle also the psychological burdens of cancer patients was made with the establishment of psycho-oncology in the mid-1970s in the USA, providing psychosocial interventions (Holland, 2002) as a complement to standard medical treatments. Since then, a variety of interventions have been the focus of research and are suggested to increase patients' well -being, such as cognitive behavioral treatments and psychoeducation (Kash, Mago, & Kunkel, 2005) . 3.1 Psychosocial interventions for cancer patients Psychosocial interventions range from counseling, coping and communication- enhancing intervention, psychoeducational intervention, cognitive -behavioral stre ss management, meaning-making interventions, art and music therapy, to meditation and relaxation interventions (Daniels & Kissane, 2008; Faller et al., 2013; Tao, Jiang, Liu, Aungsuroch, & Tao, 2015). However, results regarding the effectiveness of such interventions have been mixed (Faller et al., 2013). In a meta-analysis including 198 randomized controlled trials, Faller et al. (2013) reported that individual psychotherapy had a positive medium effect on distress, anxiety, depression and quality of life immediately after the treatment. These effects -although less pronounced - were still present up to 6 months after the intervention and for quality of life, a positive effect w as reported more than 6 months after the individual psychotherapy. Group psychotherapy had a small to medium effect size on distress, anxiety, depression and quality of life post-treatment and the effects, although reduced, were sustained 6 month or longer after the treatment, except for quality of life. For couple therapy, a small effect was found post-treatment for distress, which was not significant anymore up to 6 month or more after the treatment. For relaxation interventions, small to medium effects were reported on distress, anxiety, depression and quality of life post-treatment. Large effects for relaxation interventions on anxiety and quality of life were reported for the time period of up to 6 months after the intervention. However, sensitivity analyses indicated that 2 studies led to the large effect size and if those studies were excluded from the analyses, the effect turned non- significant. Psychoeducation had small effect on distress, anxiety, depression and quality of life 10 post-treatment, which were also present up to 6 months after the treatment, with the exception of quality of life. However, effects of psychoeducation more than 6 months after the treatment were only found for quality of life. Positive effects were also reported in other meta-analyses. Osborn and colleagues (2006) conducted a meta-analysis, where they summarized the effect of cognitive behavioral therapy ( CBT ) and patient education on cancer patients depression, anxiety, and quality of life. Their analyses showed that CBT had positive effects on cancer patients ' depression, anxiety and quality of life directly after the intervention and quality of life was improved at short and long term (R. L. Osborn et al., 2006). However, patient education did not have an effect on the outcomes of interest (R. L. Osborn et al., 2006). Another meta-analysis focusing on the effect of psychosocial interventions on anxiety and distress in cancer patients showed that the interventions had small positive effects on the outcomes of interest (Sanjida et al., 2018). However, other factors than the intervention can influence the results and therefore need to be taken into account. Faller et al. (2013) on the one hand state that publication bias (i.e. publishing of mainly positive results) may lead to an overestimation of the effects of psychosocial interventions. On the other hand, Sanjida et al. (2018) cla im that low baseline distress as one of the main reasons for the small effect sizes found in their meta-analysis. Therefore, the results from these meta-analyses should not be considered as conclusive evidence. In the following chapters, three exercises, namely mindfulness meditation, guided imagery, and progressive muscle relaxation are described in more detail. These exercises can be part of different treatments, such as cognitive behavioral therapy (Tatrow & Montgomery, 2006) or a mind-body medicine program (Carlson et al., 2017) and were the basis of this research projects intervention. 3.1.1 Mindfulness-based interventio ns Mindfulness meditation is rooted in Buddhist and Zen practices (Kabat-Zinn, Lipworth, & Burney, 1985; Speca, Carlson, Goodey, & Angen, 2000). In mindfulness meditation, the practitioner pays attention to the present moment in a nonjudgmental way (Kabat-Zinn et al., 1985) . Although many variations of mindfulness meditation exist it is often practiced in an upright sitting position and awareness to the present moment is oftentimes achieved by focusing on the sensation of breathing (Bishop et al., 2004). Effects of mindfulness 11 meditation have been studied extensively and empirical studies indicate that regular practice of mindfulness meditation can have beneficial effects on well-being and relieve stress (Goyal et al., 2014; Grossman, Niemann, Schmidt, & Walach, 2004; Hilton et al., 2017). Although the underlying mechanisms are not fully understood, empirical evidence indicate that several mechanisms such as body awareness, attention and emotion regulation induce the positive effects of mindfulness meditation (Boccia, Piccardi, & Guariglia, 2015; Gu, Strauss, Bond, & Cavanagh, 2015; Hölzel et al., 2011). The application of mindfulness meditation in clinical setting largely gained interest after the introduction of mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR), a structured 8-week program originally developed for patients with chronic pain in the 1970s. MBSR has been studied for different clinical and medical diagnoses, such as cancer, coronary artery diseases, chronic pain, anxiety, or depression (Grossman et al., 2004). Due to the success of the MBSR program, a variety of adaptations were made for specific patient populations. Mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) was initially developed as a group skills-training for relapse prevention in patients with depression (Teasdale et al., 2000). As the name implies, MBCT combines elements from MBSR and cognitive behavioral therapy. Another adaptation of MBSR specifically for cancer patients is the program mindfulness-based cancer recovery (MBCR) (Carlson et al., 2016). MBCR is a group-based program that includes mindfulness practices (e.g. mindful breathing, body scan), psychoeducation tailored towards cancer patients, and yoga exercises (Carlson & Speca, 2011). The effects of mindfulness meditation on a variety of outcomes have been summarized in various meta-analyses. Hofmann, Sawyer, Witt, and Oh (2010) summarized in a meta- analysis with 39 studies and a total of 1140 participants the effects of mindfulness-based therapies on anxiety and depression. The results showed that the interventions were moderately effective in improving anxiety and depressive symptoms in the overall sample. Focusing on patients with anxiety and mood disorders, mindfulness-based therapies yielded larger effects. Another meta-analysis (Khoury et al., 2013) reported comparable positive effect of mindfulness-based therapies on depression and anxiety. A further meta-analysis summarized the effects of MBSR on depression, anxiety, and distress in patients with chronic medical conditions (Bohlmeijer, Prenger, Taal, & Cuijpers, 2010). In total, 8 RCT were included in the analyses, which showed small effects of MBSR on depression, anxiety, and distress (Bohlmeijer et al., 2010). A meta-analysis focusing on the effect of mindfulness-based interventions for adults with chronic pain reported the combined effects of 38 RCTs. Small effects were found for pain when comparing the mindfulness intervention to treatment as usual 12 (Hilton et al., 2017) . Furthermore, mindfulness-based interventions were associated with statistically significant improvement in depression and quality of life (Hilton et al., 2017). However, the authors also stated that many of the included studies had methodological issues (e.g. small sample sizes, lack of power calculation), which is why more well-designed and larger RCTs are needed to determine more precisely the efficacy of mindfulness-based interventions (Hilton et al., 2017). As became apparent with the adapted MBCR program, mindfulness-based interventions were also implemented into cancer care. A meta-analysis conducted by Piet and colleagues (2012) summarized the effects of MBSR and MBCT on anxiety and depression in cancer patients. This meta-analysis included 22 studies, of which 9 where RCTs and 13 were nonrandomized studies. The overall results of the included studies showed a significant reduction of depression and anxiety in cancer patients, which participated in a mindfulness- based treatment (Piet, Wurtzen, & Zachariae, 2012). In another meta-analysis by Zhang et al. (2019) the effectiveness of 14 MBSR studies for breast cancer patients was summarized. The analysis revealed positive effects of MBSR on reducing anxiety, depression, fatigue and distress in cancer patients. Furthermore, the included MBSR studies showed improvements in mindfulness, cognitive function as well as emotional well-being and physical function (Zhang, Zhao, & Zheng, 2019). Although an increasing body of research indicate that mindfulness meditation can have beneficial effects, research on mindfulness interventions has also been criticized. Methodological concerns (e.g.. inappropriate use of statistics, use of unvalidated measures, lack of control variables) in mindfulness research were stated already in 2002 (Bishop, 2002). More recent studies conclude that a variety of methodological issues in mindfulness-based intervention studies still exist. For instance, the lack of validated mindfulness measures and challenges in operationalizing mindfulness as well as a strong reliance on self-reported outcomes have been reported (Van Dam et al., 2018). A systematic review aimed to assess if mindfulness research has improved methodologically (Goldberg et al., 2017). The authors concluded that the quality of mindfulness research has only improved modestly over time. For instance, sample sizes and treatment fidelity assessment increased marginally whereas no improvements regarding the lack of active control conditions or follow-up assessments were found (Goldberg et al., 2017). Therefore, effects of mindfulness interventions should currently be interpreted with caution, since reported effects in mindfulness studies might overestimate an actual benefit due to the aforementioned methodological shortcomings. To solve some of the existing methodological challenges, the use of mobile technology to deliver mindfulness-based 13 interventions has been recommended (R. J. Davidson & Dahl, 2018), which is in line with this PhD project. This mode of delivery has the benefit of a standardization of an intervention and the potential (R. J. Davidson & Dahl, 2018)to recruit large sample sizes. 3.1.2 Guided imagery and progressive muscle relaxation Guided imagery is a relaxation technique that uses stories or narratives to create images in the practitioners' mind which can lead to beneficial emotional and physical effects (Ha rt, 2008). The stories or narratives are often combined with background music (Hart, 2008) and can be delivered in a face- to-face or group setting by a therapist or an audio recording (Roffe, Schmidt, & Ernst, 2005). Besides visual images, Guided Imagery can also induce the perception of sounds, smells, tastes, sensory or affective feelings (Roffe et al., 2005). Guided Imagery has been used in a variety of patient populations with various medical conditions, such as cardiac surgery, cardiology, oncology, stroke rehabilitation, and pain management (Van Kuiken, 2004). Research on Guided Imagery indicates that it can have beneficial effects on quality of life, depression, anxiety, and pain (King, 2010). Roffe et al. (2005) reviewed studies for cancer patients that investigated Guided Imagery treatments. In this systematic review, six RCT's were included, of which only four full texts were available to the authors. Three studies reported significant effects for anxiety and comfort or emotional response to cancer therapy in the guided imagery group when compared to a control group. In a review on the effects of guided imagery on pain in cancer patients, King (2010) summarized the effects of five studies. In three studies, a decrease of pain intensity or pain-related distress was reported in the Guided Imagery group compared to a control group (King, 2010). A further study reported that Guided Imagery can have positive effects on chemotherapy induced nausea and vomiting (Hosseini, Tirgari, Forouzi, & Jahani, 2016). Another frequently used relaxation exercise is Progressive Muscle Relaxation (PMR). PMR was introduced by Jacobson in the 1920s (Sims, 1987). During PMR, different muscle groups are progressively tensed and relaxed and attention is paid to the different feelings while relaxing and tensing the muscles (Sims, 1987). PMR has shown beneficial effects in patients with tension headache, insomnia, and chronic pain in patients with inflammatory arthritis and irritable bowel syndrome (McCallie, Blum, & Hood, 2006). PMR has also been studied as a supportive treatment for symptom management in cancer patients (Satija & Bhatnagar, 2017). A systematic review by Pelekasis, Matsouka, and Koumarianou (2017) summarized the results of 5 PMR studies for cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy. The authors concluded that 14 PMR can reduce discomfort and anxiety as well as chemotherapy side effects, except for vomiting (Pelekasis et al., 2017). However, the authors also reported that the quality of the included studies were low, e.g. due to missing reports of random allocation, blinding, and sample size determination (Pelekasis et al., 2017). Another systematic review (Tian et al., 2020) summarized the effects of PMR in alleviating nausea and vomiting in cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy. This systematic review included six studies which indicate that PMR can have positive effects on nausea and, contrary to a systematic review by Pelekasis et al. (2017) also on vomiting (Tian et al., 2020). Other studies also indicate that PMR can have beneficial effects on quality of life (Cheung, Molassiotis, & Chang, 2003; Paras-Bravo et al., 2017) as well as depression and anxiety (Zhou et al., 2015) in cancer patients. Research so far suggests that guided imagery and PMR can have beneficial effects on well-being and quality of life in cancer patients. However, those relaxation exercises are oftentimes used in combination with other exercises or treatments. Some studies also investigated the effectiveness of interventions for cancer patients combining guided imagery and PMR. A systematic review by (Kapogiannis, Tsoli, & Chrousos, 2018) summarized findings of seven randomized controlled trials that investigated the effects of an intervention combining guided imagery and PMR for cancer patients. In summary, research so far indicates that the combination of guided imagery and PMR is effective in reducing anxiety and depression as well as side effects such as nausea and vomiting in cancer patients (Kapogiannis et al., 2018). 3.1.3 Barriers for uptake and adheren ce of psycho-social interventions The previous chapter highlighted that cancer patients ' mental and physical well-being is oftentimes reduced, which in turn leads to a decreased quality of life. Several psychosocial interventions can improve cancer patien ts' well -being and quality of life and therefore have been suggested as supportive treatments. However, uptake of such interventions is moderate (Brebach et al., 2016). Barriers for uptake can be stigma concerning seeking help (Cohen et al., 2018) , patients' believe that their distress is not severe and therefore does not require treatment (Clover, Mitchell, Britton, & Carter, 2015; Faller et al., 2016), lack of information about such treatments, difficulties to travel or inconvenient location of service providers (Dilworth, Higgins, Parker, Kelly, & Turner, 2014), or lack of standardized screening of distress in cancer patients (Pirl et al., 2007). 15 Studies also showed that higher levels of distress in patients does not always lead to higher uptake of psychosocial interventions (Clover et al., 2015; Tondorf et al., 2018). This is problematic, since especially patients with high levels of distress would benefit if they could reduce their distress level, due to the negative mid-term consequences of elevated levels o f distress. The lack of uptake of psychosocial interventions stands in contrast to unmet needs reported by cancer patients. Many cancer patients state that their needs in psychosocial domains oftentimes are not met (Willems et al., 2016; Zhu et al., 2018). Furthermore, more unmet needs in cancer patients are correlated with lower quality of life (Willems et al., 2016; Zhu et al., 2018). To tackle this discrepancy between need and uptake of psychosocial interventions , amongst others, digital self-care interventions have been proposed, which is the topic of the next chapter. 16 4. Digital interventions Digital interventions are programs using digital technology such as mobile apps, social media, and interactive websites which aim to foster behavior change to improve the health of professionals, patients, or the general public (Michie, Yardley, West, Patrick, & Greaves, 2017). Digital interventions aiming at improving health are also labeled eHealth interventions. Although a precise definition of eHealth is lacking, the majority of definitions describe eHealth as the use of technology (e.g. the internet, information and communication technologies) to improve health (Oh et al., 2005). Access to digital technology like the internet and the ownership of digital devices like smartphones have increased largely over the last couple of years (Dugas, Gao, & Agarwal, 2020; McKay et al., 2018).Therefore, digital interventions have been proposed as a mean to improve health behaviors and health care, although research in this field is still preliminary (Michie et al., 2017). Digital interventions have been proposed for a variety of medical conditions and research indicates that such interventions can be effective. For example, digital interventions for hypertension patients have been shown to significantly lower patients' blood pressure when compared to usual care (McLean et al., 2016). In addition, digital interventions show promising effects in glycemic control and self-management in patients with diabetes (Liang et al., 2011) can also help overweight and obese adults to lose weight (Beleigoli et al., 2019) and have been found to be helpful for the prevention of cardiovascular disease (Widmer et al., 2015), smoking cessation (Graham et al., 2016; Taylor et al., 2017). Furthermore, digital interventions can also be effective in improving mental health. A meta-analysis conducted by Firth and colleagues indicates that digital interventions compared to a control condition can significantly reduce depressive symptoms (Firth et al., 2017). Digital interventions can also be effective in reducing anxiety (Deady et al., 2017; Firth et al., 2017). People diagnosed with a cancer diagnosis might also benefit from digital interventions. A review by Escriva Boulley et al. (2018) concluded that digital interventions with psychosocial components (e.g. psychoeducation, psychological support, coping strategies) show promising effects in cancer patients as well as cancer survivors. However, the methodological quality of most studies was judged to be poor and hence evidence for efficacy is still limited (Escriva Boulley et al., 2018; Marcolino et al., 2018). Positive effects were for instance reported in a RCT conducted by Willems et al. (2017), in which a web-based computer-tailored intervention with principles from problem solving therapy and CBT reduced depression and fatigue and 17 increased the emotional and social functioning in cancer survivors. These findings are supported by a review by Seiler, Klaas, Troster, and Fagundes (2017) that also found beneficial effects of a variety of digital interventions (e.g. educational programs, CBT- or MBSR-based) on fatigue and depression and health related quality of life in nine studies. Another RCT investigating a web-based self-care intervention for cancer patients reported beneficial effects on depressive symptoms (Fann, Hong, Halpenny, Blonquist, & Berry, 2017). Furthermore , some studies also investigated online mindfulness-based interventions for cancer patients. In a pilot RCT, 46 cancer patients in the intervention group receiving a 6-week online mindfulness- based intervention were compared to a control group with 23 cancer patients (Russell et al., 2019). The results of this study indicate that the severity of fear of cancer recurrence (one of seven domains of the fear of cancer recurrence inventory) significantly improved in the intervention group compared to the control group. However, no significant differences were found in other domains of the fear of recurrence inventory (e.g. psychological distress, functional impairment) or in other measures assessing rumination, mindfulness, worry, and perceived stress (Russell et al., 2019). Another RCT with three arms (treatment as usual, group face- to-face or individual internet-based mindfulness-based cognitive therapy) investigated long-term effects of mindfulness-based interventions for cancer patients (Cillessen et al., 2018). Results showed that in both intervention groups distress, rumination, mental health and quality of life improved significantly, wher eas patients in the online intervention group reported lower distress at follow-up compared to patients in the group intervention (Cillessen et al., 2018). In addition to those effects, the acceptability of digital interventions seems high. In two studies measuring acceptability, 72% and 57 % of cancer patients judged the respective digital intervention to be helpful (Damholdt et al., 2016; Russell et al., 2019). However, research indicates that it is important that the intervention is delivered at the right stage of the cancer treatment and that the intervention content is specifically matched to the patients changing needs (Corbett et al., 2018). 4.1 mHealth interventions A subcategory of eHealth is mHealth, which is defined as the use of mobile technologies (e.g. smartphones, tablets) for the delivery of health services (Kay, Santos, & Takane, 2011). A major advantage of mHealth interventions compared to web-based interventions is the accessibility. Since a mobile device such as a smartphone is used, the intervention can be accessed at any place. Furthermore, the number of smartphone owners has grown rapidly 18 worldwide (Finances Online, 2020; Pew Research Center, 2019), which increases the possible access to mHealth interventions also to hard- to-reach populations. In Switzerland, it is estimated that 90% of people own a smartphone (Statista Research Department, 2020) and most people access the internet today through their smartphone (Bundesamt für Statistik, 2020). Whittaker, McRobbie, Bullen, Rodgers, and Gu (2016) defined advantages of using mobile interventions as convenience, ease, cost effectiveness, scalability, personalization, and the ability to send time-sensitive messages with. Another advantage of a mobile phone is the possibility to send and receive reminders, for instance in form of short message service (SMS). Marcolino et al. (2018) showed evidence, that SMS reminders significantly enhanced attendance rates and improved adherence to therapy which is one of the key points when it comes to the successful implementation of an intervention. However, beside of all the above-mentioned advantages, also some disadvantages and limitations have to be considered. Disadvantages of mHealth interventions include for example unequal access to or limited knowledge of information and communication technology, which can negatively impact the uptake of an mHealth intervention (Hamine, Gerth-Guyette, Faulx, Green, & Ginsburg, 2015). Further limitations can occur due to privacy regulations, which can hinder the implementation of mHealth interventions (Vogel, Combs, & Kessel, 2017). Current rapid technological advances also inhibi t timely evaluation of new mHealth developments since rigorous research is time-consuming (Goldfine, Lai, Lucey, Newcomb, & Carreiro, 2020) . Furthermore, a large number of mHealth interventions are continuously released and the majority of openly available mHealth apps are developed by the software industry and lack scientific evidence (Donker et al., 2013; Lau et al., 2020; Marcolino et al., 2018). Therefore, health professionals as well as patients might have difficulties in finding an appropriate and effective mHealth intervention. Despite these limitations and possible disadvantages, mHealth interventions show similarly to eHealth interventions promising results on health outcomes. For instance, studies report positive effects of mHealth interventions on mental health (Wang, Varma, & Prosperi, 2018), smoking cessation, weight loss, increase of physical activity (Flores Mateo, Granado- Font, Ferre-Grau, & Montana-Carreras, 2015), medication intake, and diabetes (Tabi et al., 2019). mHealth interventions are also promising in cancer patients. One randomized controlle d study conducted by Rosen, Paniagua, Kazanis, Jones, and Potter (2018) investigated the effect of a 8 week mobile app-delivered mindfulness training on quality of life in 112 women 19 diagnosed with breast cancer. They found that as compared to the waitlist control group, the app group reported a higher quality of life after 8 weeks of training. This effect was still present after 4 weeks. Also in breast cancer survivors, mHealth interventions were successfully applied. Lengacher et al. (2018) for example provided 15 breast cancer survivors with a 6 weeks mobile mindfulness-based stress reduction for breast cancer program. From baseline to post 6 weeks beneficial effects in the following parameters were showed: depression, state anxiety, stress, fear of recurrence, sleep, fatigue and quality of life. Although the sample was rather small, hence they concluded, that the effects of a mHealth intervention on several psychological and physiological parameters might be promising. However, research on mHealth for cancer patients is sparse and partially showing mixed results. In a systematic review summarizing studies to support self-management for adult cancer survivors and their outcome on pain, psychological distress, fatigue, or sleep outcomes, only seven studies were included of which only two were RCTs (Hernandez Silva, Lawler, & Langbecker, 2019). Although research so far indicates that mHealth intervention for cancer survivors can improve pain, fatigue, and sleep outcomes, further studies are necessary to confirm the effectiveness of mHealth interventions, as well as to determine limitations of such interventions (Hernandez Silva et al., 2019). Other studies show that mHealth interventions can be beneficial in improving cancer patients ' quality of life, although results so far on the effect of psychological outcomes such as distress are inconclusive (Jongerius, Russo, Mazzocco, & Pravettoni, 2019; J. Osborn, Ajakaiye, Cooksley, & Subbe, 2020) 20 B. EMPIRICAL STUDIES 1. Aims of the PhD project The aims of this thesis was to evaluate the feasibility of a mindfulness- and relaxation- based app intervention for cancer patients. To achieve this, we first conducted a systematic review where we summarized results from relaxation-based eHealth studies for patients with a medical condition. Second, we conducted a mindfulness- and relaxation-based app study for cancer patients. In this prospective observational study, all enrolled cancer patients received access to the app and patient reported outcomes as well as data on app usage were collected over the course of 20 weeks. We used a mixed-methods design and therefore collected and analyzed quantitative and qualitative data. Quantitative data comprised self-reported health outcomes, which we assessed with paper and pencil questioners and partly electronically with the app. Additional quantitative data were app usage data. Qualitative data were assessed with semi-structured interviews, which we conducted with patients and health professionals. The study was guided by the RE-AIM evaluation framework, which assesses the following evaluations dimensions: Reach, effectiveness, adoption, implementation, and maintenance. This research project was funded by the Swiss Cancer League (funding ID: KLS-3564-02-2015) and was conducted at the Institute for Complementary and Integrative Medicine, University Hospital Zurich and University of Zurich. 2. Methods 2.1 App Intervention For this research project a mindfulness and relaxation app for cancer patients was developed. The app built on previously developed relaxation study-apps of an affiliated group (Blodt, Pach, Roll, & Witt, 2014) which were designed for patients with chronic low back pain (Relaxback) and chronic neck pain (Relaxneck). The app was developed by the software company Smart Mobile Factory GmbH (Berlin, Germany). After thorough testing, the app was released in June 2016 on the Apple iTunes store and on the Google Play Store for Android devices. After the final release, the content of the app was not changed. The app could be publicly downloaded for free, however, an individual access code was needed to start the app. 21 This access code exclusively known by the study team was distributed to study participants after a screening for eligibility and a subsequent inclusion into the study. The app consisted of three main features: (1) guided audio mindfulness and relaxation exercises, (2) a notification feature, and (3) a brief questionnaire. The first feature comprised three different exercises that were audio recordings of mindfulness meditation, guided imagery, and progressive muscle relaxation exercises (see Fig. 1). Each audio file was about 15 minutes long and voiced either by a male or a female narrator. The second feature of the app was an optional notification feature, which could be used to get a reminder to practice daily. The reminder popped up as a push notification on the mobile device every day at the time set by the patient according to his individual preferences (see Fig. 2). If the patients considered the daily reminder as too stressful, this feature could also be deactivated. The third feature of the app was a weekly questionnaire, which assessed distress levels and user satisfaction with the app (see Fig. 3). All features were accessible through the app menu (see Fig. 4). Figure 1. Screenshots of the CanRelax App exercises 22 Figure 2. Screenshots of the CanRelax App notification feature. Figure 3. Screenshots of the CanRelax App questionnaire. 23 Figure 4. Screenshots of the CanRelax App menu. 2.2 Measur es In our study we used a mixed-methods approach, combining quantitative and qualitative methods. For quantitative data, we used several questionnaires to assess quality of life and health related outcomes. Furthermore, our research app generated a logfile in which patients' time spent using the app exercises was recorded. For qualitative data, we conducted semi- structured interviews with cancer patients and health professionals. 2.2.1 Assessment of quantitative data In this research project, we used a variety of questionnaires to assess quantitative date over the course of 20 weeks. The matrix of measures with a list of all questionnaires is depicted in figure 3. These questionnaires are outlined in more detail in the methods section of our publications. 25 about topics that were relevant to them. The interviews were recorded, transcribed verbatim and then thematic coding for structuring the interviews was applied using the software MAXQDA (Version 11, VERBI Software, Berlin Germany). Thereafter, for analysis, content analysis according to Mayring (2010) was used. 26 3. Published studies The above mentioned research aims resulted in three published manuscripts (Mikolasek, Berg, Witt, & Barth, 2018; Mikolasek, Witt, & Barth, 2018, 2021). The first manuscript was a systematic review with the aim to summarize the current state of knowledge about the effectiveness of mindfulness- and relaxation-based eHealth interventions for patients with medical conditions. The latter two manuscripts evaluated the feasibility of our research app for cancer patients. One addressed the three evaluation dimension reach, adoption, and maintenance of our mindfulness and relaxation self-care app for cancer patients and the other highlighted the effects and the implementation of the same intervention app. The content of the three manuscripts is described in full detail in the subsequent paragraphs. 27 3.1 Effectiveness of mindfulness-and relaxation-based eHealth interventions for patients with medical conditions: a systematic review and synthesis This article was originally published in: Mikolasek, M., Berg, J., Witt, C. M., & Barth, J. (2018). Effectiveness of mindfulness-and relaxation-based eHealth interventions for patients with medical conditions: a systematic review and synthesis. International journal of behavioral medicine,25(1), 1-16. doi: 10.1007/s12529-017-9679-7 Effectiveness of Mindfulness- and Relaxation-Based eHealth Interventions for Patients with Medical Conditions: a Systematic Review and Synthesis Michael Mikolasek1&Jonas Berg1&Claudia M. Witt1,2,3&Jürgen Barth1 Published online: 27 July 2017 #International Society of Behavioral Medicine 2017 Abstract Purpose This systematic review aims to summarize eHealth studies with mindfulness- and relaxation-based interventions for medical conditions and to determine whether eHealth in- terventions have positive effects on health. Method A comprehensive search of five databases was con- ducted for all available studies from 1990 to 2015. Studies were included if the intervention was mainly technology delivered and included a mindfulness- or relaxation-based intervention strategy and if patients with a medical condition were treated. Treatment effects were summarized for different outcomes. Results A total of 2383 records were identified, of which 17 studies with 1855 patients were included in this systematic review. These studies were conducted in patients with irritable bowel syndrome, chronic fatigue syndrome, cancer, chronic pain, surgery, and hypertension. All but one study were deliv- ered online through a web-based platform; one study delivered the intervention with iPods. The studies indicate that mindfulness- and relaxation-based eHealth interventions can have positive effects on patients 'general health and psycholog- ical well-being. No effects were found for stress or mindfulness. Only five studies reported economic analyses of eHealth inter- ventions without any clear conclusion.Conclusion There is some evidence that mindfulness- and relaxation-based eHealth interventions for medical conditions can have positive effects on health outcomes. Therefore, such interventions might be a useful addition to standard medical care. No app studies were retrieved, even though a vast num- ber of smartphone apps exist which aim at increasing users ' health. Therefore, more studies investigating those health apps are needed. Keywords Mindfulness .Relaxation techniques .eHealth . Smartphone .Patients .Study quality Introduction eHealth is defined by the World Health Organization (WHO) asthe use of information and communication technologies for health [ 1]. The number of eHealth studies is increasing, and eHealth interventions are effective at improving patients ' health [ 2]. One of the most important advantages of eHealth is its high accessibility due to the well-established access to the Internet by the majority of people worldwide, which also allows remotely located people or those with reduced mobility access to care [ 3]. Another advantage of eHealth interventions is reduced healthcare costs, since relatively few economic and personnel resources are needed for delivery compared to face- to-face interventions [ 2]. eHealth interventions can use a va- riety of intervention strategies to improve patients 'health, such as education, feedback, exercise, and verbal support with a therapist or other patients [ 4]. Changing patients 'cognition and behavior can be regarded as the underlying working mechanism for such interventions. In recent years, setting up and maintaining an eHealth intervention were greatly facili- tated due to technological advances like Web 2.0 [ 5].*Michael Mikolasek michael.mikolasek@usz.ch 1Institute for Complementary and Integrative Medicine, University Hospital Zurich and University of Zurich, Sonneggstrasse 6, 8091 Zurich, Switzerland 2Institute for Social Medicine, Epidemiology and Health Economics, Charité -Universitätsmedizin Berlin, Berlin, Germany 3Center for Integrative Medicine, University of Maryland School of Medicine, Baltimore, MD, USAInt.J. Behav. Med. (2018) 25:1 -16 DOI 10.1007/s12529-017-9679-7 28The mode of delivery and format of eHealth interven- tions vary considerably. For instance, audio, video, or text can convey educational information or various exercises, while an eHealth intervention might incorporate contact with a therapist (e.g., via e-mail, chat, telephone) or with other users (e.g., via forum). Also, a variety of platforms like PCs, tablets, or smartphones can be used to deliver an eHealth intervention, making eHealth a broad topic with numerous different definitions [ 6]. Aconsiderable number of eHealth studies also incorporate mindfulness- and relaxation-based intervention strategies. The rationale for this might be the evidence of many studies with a beneficial effect of mindfulness- and relaxation-based inter- ventions in a face-to-face setting for patients with medical conditions [ 7-10]. The practice of mindfulness is rooted in Buddhist traditions [ 11] and has been implemented into Western healthcare interventions, independent of a religious and cultural context [ 12]. Mindfulness consists of intentional attention in the present moment and an openness and accep- tance towards this experience [ 13]. The non-judgmental expe- rience of body sensations is often part of mindfulness inter- ventions. It is hypothesized that this experience leads to in- creased self-regulation and emotional, cognitive, and behav- ioral flexibility [ 12]. The underlying mechanism is therefore an adaptation to the present moment by reducing the impact of wearing information through acceptance. On the contrary, traditional relaxation interventions such as progressive muscle relaxation [ 14] are rooted in Western society and focus directly on relaxation by means of exercises (e.g., progressive muscle relaxation) or imagina- tion (e.g., guided imagery) [ 15]. The underlying mechanism is a physiological response (e.g., decreased heart rate and blood pressure) by body exercises or the manipulation of thoughts [16,17]. Despite those differences, both mindfulness practices and relaxation methods elicit a relaxation response (i.e., decreased psychophysiological arousal) [ 15,18]. These similar responses are congr uent with findings indicating that mindfulness- and relaxation-based interventions are effective in reducing distress in patients with hard-to-treat or chronic medical conditions [ 19-21]. Mindfulness- and relaxation-based interventions can also be delivered in meth- odologically similar ways (e.g., multi-week and multimodal clinical interventions) [ 22]. In addition, both kinds of in- terventions are effectively used to increase patients 'self- care [ 23,24] and, compared to other stress-reducing in- terventions such as biofeedback [ 25], no additional equip- ment is required. Mindfulness- and relaxation-based eHealth interventions might be a good alternative or addition to face-to-face inter- ventions for patients with high psychological burden, since eHealth interventions are low threshold (i.e., patients do not need to leave their home for the intervention) [ 26]. Therefore,eHealth interventions as an addition to standard care might be particularly suited for patients with a high frequency of med- ical visits or impaired mobility. Two recent reviews [ 27,28] summarized the effects of mindfulness-basedeHealth interventions, indicating that these eHealth interventions can contribute to improve outcomes such as stress, depression, and anxiety. However, both reviews included studies with a large variety in the population, ranging from healthy volunteers (i.e., mainly student population) to patients with medical or psychological conditions. Patients with medical conditions often suffer from increased rates of depression, anxiety, and distress, as well as a reduced quality of life [ 29-32]. Therefore, a focused perspective on eHealth interventions for patients with medical conditions is advisable to allow conclusions for such users. To draw more conclusive findings for patients with medical conditions, the aim of this syst ematic review was to summarize the effectiveness of mindfulness- and relaxation-based eHealth studies for patients with medical conditions. Since we were interested in summarizing the effectiveness (i.e., effects in a routine clinical setting) of mindf ulness- and relaxation-based interventions, we included studies which combine various types of interventions. Method Eligibility Criteria Studies were included if they conducted a pre- and post- assessment of a health outcome of interest (general health, depression or anxiety, stress, mindfulness, satisfaction with the intervention, self-efficacy or self-care, pain or other health-related outcomes) for an eHealth intervention in adult patients with medical conditions (e.g., cancer, hypertension, fibromyalgia). Studies were excluded if patients suffered sole- ly from mental disorders (i.e., 10th revision of the International Statistical Classification of Diseases and Related Health Problems (IC D-10) diagnosis codes F01 - F99), which also led to the exclusion of addiction or substance abuse (ICD-10 diagnosis code F10 -F19). Studies with pa- tients suffering from disorders which could be considered ei- ther a medical condition or a mental disorder (e.g., sleep dis- orders: ICD-10 code F51 or G47) were excluded. In each study, a mindfulness or relaxation intervention strategy had to be a substantial part of the intervention (see Table 1). Studies with various intervention strategies (e.g., mindfulness meditatio n, relaxation, patient educa- tion, and biofeedback) were only included if the ratio of mindfulness or relaxation intervention strategy to the total number of intervention strategies was at least 1 to 5. Furthermore, the intervention had to be mainly technolo- gy delivered. We considered an intervention as technology2 Int.J. Behav. Med. (2018) 25:1 -16 29delivered if it was accessed via the internet or a smartphone app, if face-to-face meetings between patients and the study team were restricted to data collection, and if the contact with a therapist was restricted to one face-to-face contact. However, we included studies if they comprised online, e-mail, or phone contact with the therapist as part of the intervention (see Table 1). The studies had to include at least pre- and post- assessments of any kind of health-related outcome (e.g., qual- ity of life, stress), but the design did not have to be controlled (i.e., including a comparison group). We included all journal publications published in any language between 1990 and April 2015. The reason for this timeframe for inclusion is that during the 1990s, the internet was established for public use [6]. During the screening process, we excluded dissertations due to limited access to unpublished work and a lack of clarity regarding peer review. Search Strategy and Study Selection For the literature search, we used three databases in EBSCO (PsycINFO, CINAHL, and AMED) and two additional data- bases (EMBASE and Medline). We searched for the following terms (full list of keywords in Appendix ):Bapp or online context ^AND Bmindfulness or relaxation ^AND Bintervention or rct or treatment. ^For exclusion, the following terms were used: Babuse or alcohol or addiction. ^ Our team consisted of four researchers, who were trained with a screening manual for study inclusion. We based the screening manual on previous systematic reviews performed by our group and adapted it to the specific require- ments (e.g., inclusion criteria, outcomes) for this systematic review. Three researchers conducted the abstract screening (JB, JoB, IM), and three researchers conducted the full-text screening (JB, JoB, MM). After the literature search and after the removal of duplicates, all abstracts were screened accord- ing to a structured manual. Subsequently, the full texts of included articles were screened using the same predefined eligibility criteria.Data Extraction All researchers involved in the data extraction (JB, JoB, MM) were trained using the extraction manual with five studies for training purposes. During the training, we discussed the re- sults and clarified any terminological ambiguity. After the training, all studies were extracted in duplicate (JoB, MM) and the extraction of data was done in Excel according to a standardized extraction manual. In cases of disagreement re- garding the extracted data, consensus was reached with a third researcher (JB). We extracted general information about the study (first au- thor and publication year), data on patients (number of pa- tients in intervention and control groups, inclusion and exclu- sion criteria), intervention (mode of delivery, intervention strategy, dose, and length of intervention), comparators, out- comes, and study design. For the extraction of interventio n strategies, we prespecified the following categories: mindfulness, relaxation, patient edu- cation, biofeedback, cognitive intervention, exercise (including Yoga, Tai Chi), imagination or visualization, and meditation other than mindfulness. As outcomes of interest, we pr especified the following categories: general health (defined as measures assessing physical functioning, disability or quality of life), depres- sion or anxiety, stress, mindfulness, satisfaction with the intervention, self-efficacy or self-care, pain, or other health-related outcomes. The effectiveness of the eHealth intervention was evaluated by a vote counting approach, in which the number of studies with positive effects was compared to the number of studies with negative effects [33]. For randomized controlled trials (RCTs), a signifi- cant effect was defined as superior effectiveness if the results favored the intervention group. A non-significant effect was defined as equal effectiveness. A significant effect was de- fined as inferior effectiveness if the results favored the control group. For pretest-posttest studies without a control group, a significant change over time was considered a positive re- sponse. Insignificant improvement over time was consideredTable 1 Operationalization of technology-delivered, mindfulness- and relaxation- based interventionsTechnology-delivered interventionThe intervention must be accessed through an online-login (e.g., accessing a web browser program) or smartphone app. Face-to-face meeting between patients and study team is restricted to pre-, post-, and follow-up data collection. Supplementary communication between patients and therapist is restricted to face-to-face contact only once. Online, e-mail, or phone contact is allowed if supplementary to the online intervention. Mindfulness- and relaxation-based interventionAll interventions based on aspects of mindfulness and relaxation are included. This means that standardized courses like mindfulness-based stress reduction (MBSR) or mindfulness-based cognitive therapy (MBCT) is included, as well as intervention based on other meditation practices (e.g., metta meditation), mind-body awareness, and relaxation techniques.Int.J. Behav. Med. (2018) 25:1 -16 3 30no response, and deterioration over time was considered a negative response. pvalues lower than .05 were considered significant. We report standardized mean differences between groups which are either reported by the authors or derived from information given in the publication by transformation routines. Quality Assessment For the assessment of risk of bias, two researchers (JB, MM) assessed the adequate random sequence generation ( =0 . 7 0 ) and allocation concealment 0.86) for each study accord- ing to Cochrane standards [ 33] in duplicate. In cases of dis- agreement, consensus was reached in a discussion between the two researchers. Blinding of the Cochrane Risk of Bias Tool [ 33] was not rated, since blinding might be considered inadequate according to Cochrane standards in all studies with self-report measures, which is the gold standard in this type of research. We did not assess completeness of outcome assess- ment in a regular way, but we extracted the number of drop- outs, which reflects the feasibility of the interventions. We defined dropouts as the number of patients who were allocated to the eHealth intervention or control group but did not com- plete the post-treatment assessment. For the assessment of the external validity of each study, we used one item of the checklist by Downs and Black [ 34], namely if the patients in the study were representative for the entire patient population (i.e., patients comprise the entire source population, an unselected sample of consecutive pa- tients, or a random sample) ( = 0.61). Two researchers (JB, MM) rated the items individually for each study. In cases of disagreement, the same researchers reached consensus in a discussion. Data Synthesis We pooled the findings of the studies according to the six outcomes and stratified for the type of control condition (usual care, waitlist vs. active control, attention control). The find- ings were summarized in a vote counting approach, with all non-significant findings being reported as a null effect, which is a quite conservative approach. We used this approach since the outcomes of the studies and the underlying medical con- ditions vary substantially between studies and homogeneity in effects cannot be expected in a pooled meta-analysis. Results Study Selection Through the literature search, a total of 2703 records were identified. After removal of 323 duplicates, titles and abstractswere screened in 2383 records. Subsequently, 2257 studies were excluded because they did not match our inclusion criteria. The full texts of the remaining 126 studies were screened; of these, 109 did not meet our inclusion criteria. Finally, a total of 17 studies met our inclusion criteria and were included in this review (Fig. 1). Study Characteristics An overview of the 17 included studies [ 35-51]i sp r e s e n t e di n Table 2. Three studies [ 41,42,51] were published between 2000 and 2005, a further three studies [ 38,47,50]w e r ep u b - lished between 2006 and 2010, and 11 studies [ 35-37,39,40, 43-46,48,49] were published between 2011 and 2015. Regarding the study designs, 15 studies [ 35,37-45,47-51] were randomized. One study [ 36] used a control group without randomization, and one study [ 46] used a pretest-posttest de- sign. Patients in the studies suffered from eight different med- ical conditions. Five studies [ 35,45,47-49] conducted an eHealth intervention for irrita ble bowel syndrome, three studies [41,44,51] for headache, two studies [ 37,39] for cancer, two studies [ 38,42] for chronic pain, two studies [ 40,45] for fibro- myalgia, one study [ 43] for surgery, and one study [ 50]f o r hypertension. All but one study were delivered online (i.e., access through a web browser). One study [ 43] delivered the eHealth intervention with iPods (i.e., relaxing music). The study-specific charact eristics are summarized in Table 3. The included studies involved a total of 1855 patients, with a range from 18 to 368 patients per study. The duration of the eHealth interventions ranged from 10 days to 10 weeks. Congruent with our inclusion criteria, all studies had at least an intervention strategy consisting of mindfulness (11 studies [35-37,39,40,42,45-49]) or relaxation (9 studies [ 36-39,41, 43,44,50,51]). Three of those studies [ 36,37,39] used both mindfulness and relaxation inte rvention strategies. The major- ity of studies included additionally patient education (14 studies [35,37-42,44-49,51]) or cognitive intervention (13 studies [35,37-42,44-49]) as an intervention strategy. Less common- ly used intervention strategies were biofeedback [ 41,50], other meditation techniques than mindfulness [ 36,37], and imagina- tion or visualization [ 36,39]. None of the studies used body exercise as an intervention strategy. Furthermore, 11 studies used additional intervention strategies which were not included in our classification (e.g., e xposure treatment, writing exercises). Except for one [ 43], all studies used more than one inter- vention strategy according to our classification. Two studies [37,39] used six intervention strategies, ten studies [ 35,36, 38,40,41,44-48]used four intervention strategies, three studies [ 42,49,51] used three intervention strategies, and one study [ 50] used two intervention strategies. The intervention strategies in the active control groups were online chat forum [ 35], online symptom management4 Int.J. Behav. Med. (2018) 25:1 -16 31program [ 36], information via website [ 37], health tips [ 40], online diary [ 41], online pain management with psychoeducation [ 42], internet-delivered stress management [48], and internet-delivered cognitive behavior therapy with exposure [ 49]. Quality of Studies Concerning the quality of the sequence generation, 11 studies of the 15 RCTs [ 37-40,42,44,45,47-49,51] had a low risk of bias and four studies [ 35,41,43,50] had an unclear risk of bias. The allocation concealment was performed well in ten studies [ 37,40,42,44,45,47-51] with a low risk of bias, and five studies [ 35,38,39,41,43] had an unclear risk of bias. In 12 studies [ 35,37-39,42-45,48-51], the subjects were rep- resentative of the population; in four studies [ 36,40,41,47], they were not, and in one study [ 46], representativeness could not be determined (see Table 4).The assessment of the risk of bias items was not applicable for one study by Ljotsson et al. [46], which was a pretest-posttest study without a control group. Effectiveness of Mindfulness-Related eHealth Interventions The most common outcome was general health, which was assessed in 13 studies [ 36,37,39-41,44-51]( s e eT a b l e 5). Depression or anxiety was assessed in 11 studies [ 37,38,40-43,46-49,51]. Pain was assessed in nine studies [ 38, 40-44,46,47,51]. Self-efficacy or self-care [ 38-40,43, 44], stress [ 37,48], and mindfulness [ 36,42], and satisfaction with the intervention [ 38,39]w e r el e s sc o m m o n l ya s s e s s e d . Most studies used validated questionnaires for the assessment of outcomes of interest (see Table 5). Exceptions were scales developed by investigators or modified items [ 40] and diaries [40,44,47,51] which were used to complement questionnaires. Twelve of 13 studies with general health as outcome were RCTs. Eight studies used an active control group, of which five studies [ 40,41,45,47,48] reported superior effectiveness of the eHealth intervention. One study [ 46] used a pretest-posttest design indicating a pos- itive response of the eHealth intervention. Discussion This systematic review found evidence that eHealth interven- tions with mindfulness- or relaxation-based strategies might be effective for increasing patients 'general health and well- being. More than half of the studies reported positive effects on general health (i.e., physical functioning, disability, quality of life), depression, anxiety, or self-efficacy. Fewer studies reported positive effects of eHealth interventions on pain, and no study reported positive effects on stress or mindful- ness. Overall, these findings are of clinical relevance since all studies used eHealth interventio ns for difficult-to-treat or chronic medical conditions.
