JMIR Cancer 2021 | vol. 7 | iss. 1 | e16785 | p. 8 https://cancer.jmir.org/2021/1/e16785 (page number not for citation purposes)Mikolasek et al JMIR CANCER XSL·FO RenderX69Implementation A total of 5 health professionals took part in an interview: 2 female nursing experts (one from an inpatient unit and the other from an outpatient oncology unit), 2 female MBM psychologists, and 1 male oncologist. Interviews were conducted between January and March 2018 and lasted for an average of 45 minutes (SD 9.54). The qualitative analysis of the interviews yielded 4 themes: (1) general impression of the app, (2) suggestions for improvement, (3) implementation in standard care, and (4) experience with recommending the app to patients. Overall, the general impression of the app was positive. For instance, the oncologist summarized his impression of the app as follows: I think [the app] is a very helpful thing because it is relatively easy [to use]. You can test it. You can try it and if you like it, you can integrate it relatively easy into everyday life. I think it is very practical. It is a practical thing and if patients are interested, I also see that they take it up willingly. All health professionals perceived the app as appealing, clearly structured, and as a helpful supportive tool. In addition, the MBM psychologists liked the app as an addition to the 10-week face-to-face MBM course and appreciated the app as a good self-help tool complementing the course. The oncologist also stated that many patients with cancer look for something they can use to add to standard care and an app can provide a low threshold aid. As a negative aspect, a nursing expert stated that a smartphone is required and not every patient possesses such a device. All health experts made various suggestions for improving the app. A shared opinion was that the content of the app (ie, number and variety of exercises) could be increased, as over an extended period, patients might get bored with a choice limited to 3 exercises. A nursing expert suggested that a new exercise could, for instance, be unlocked after completing the same exercise several times. An MBM psychologist suggested that every week, a different selection of exercises could be activated with alternating topics such as meditation, relaxation, self-compassion, or body exercises. In addition, the inclusion of exercises with different degrees of complexity was suggested. An MBM psychologist stated that exercises for beginners (eg, more detailed instructions, fewer moments of silence) as well as exercises for patients experienced in mindfulness and relaxation could be added. MBM psychologists and nursing experts also recommended that some exercises should be accompanied by soothing background music because longer periods of silence might be uncomfortable for some patients. They also recommended exercises with various lengths of time so that patients had more flexibility if they were facing time constraints or if they were too impatient for longer exercises. The oncologist mentioned that adding exercises specifically for sleep disorders might be a good addition to the app, especially for inpatients, because poor sleep in hospitals is very common. As an additional topic that could be added, he mentioned body exercises such as yoga. An MBM psychologist mentioned that an app mirroring the MBM course more closely would be great:If I could make a wish, then I would say, it would be totally cool to have an accompanying Mind Body Medicine app. That is to say that a lot of exercises—not all of them—b ut a lot of exercises we do [could be added to the app]. Possibly also guided body exercises. That would be totally cool. The interviewees mentioned several factors that could influence the implementation of a mindfulness- and relaxation-based app into standard care. Both nursing experts and one of the MBM psychologists stated that the time point when the information of the app is delivered to the patient might be important. These health professionals mentioned that the patients were bombarded with information during the first consultation or during the first day when a patient enters the hospital and additional information about the app might overwhelm some patients. The outpatient nursing expert also mentioned that they are often limited because of time constraints during consultation hours: On the one hand there are the concerns of the patients, which you have to discuss. But you also have a little bit of pressure, [to tell them] all relevant information. [...] And sometimes it's already two minutes before the end [of the consultation]. [...] And you can't just hand out the flyer. You also need to say a few words [about the app] and that's why I sometimes forgot [to mention the app]. Due to shortage of time. The nursing experts also mentioned that the nurses oftentimes forgot about the app because it is not part of standard care. Therefore, the nursing experts stated that it might be helpful to better inform the nurses about the app and setting up standards regarding the communication about the app, for example, when to inform the patients and how. In addition, the nursing experts stated that it might be helpful if they had a demonstration device at the oncology unit so that they could better explain the app to the patients. All interviewed health professionals further mentioned that patients with cancer are very diverse and that although some patients are very eager to try out various treatments, others are not. One MBM therapist also stated that not all patients perceive relaxation as important and that those patients might need some additional information which indicates why relaxation is good for them. All health professionals also stated that implementing such an app does not result in a lot of additional work for them and they appreciate the app, which they could recommend to suitable patients. Regarding their experience with recommending the app to patients, health professionals shared the opinion that female patients are more drawn to mindfulness and relaxation exercises. Furthermore, the MBM therapists stated that patients who already practiced some form of relaxation or meditation often did not participate in the study. The MBM therapists also noticed that the composition of the MBM group had an influence on how many patients were willing to try out the app. For instance, if one patient was very motivated and expressed interest in the app, hesitant patients sometimes followed suit and were willing to try the app as well. One MBM therapist also noticed that many older people were willing to use the app: JMIR Cancer 2021 | vol. 7 | iss. 1 | e16785 | p. 9 https://cancer.jmir.org/2021/1/e16785 (page number not for citation purposes)Mikolasek et al JMIR CANCER XSL·FO RenderX70I was surprised that so many older patients had the app on their phone and also used the app regularly [...]. I had the impression, that it appeals to the young. [...]. But oftentimes, the older people have more time, because they don't work anymore. Discussion Principal Findings In this study, we explored the feasibility of a mindfulness- and relaxation-based self-help app for patients with cancer. To evaluate the feasibility, we used the RE-AIM framework [ 37], and in this analysis, we focused on the framework dimensions effectiveness, adoption, and implementation. Our findings support the feasibility of this mHealth intervention. The results indicate that the intervention might have beneficial effects on patients' distress and quality of life. Furthermore, the mHealth intervention is accepted by the target population as well as by health professionals. For the dimension effectiveness, we looked into pre-post effects. Our results suggest that the app might have the potential to reduce distress, fatigue, sleep disturbance, and anxiety as well as improve health-related quality of life and mindfulness. This is in line with a recent pilot study [ 47], in which a mobile mindfulness-based stress reduction program improved, among others, stress, anxiety, depression, sleep quality, quality of life, and mindfulness in patients with breast cancer with small to large effects. Furthermore, a recent randomized controlled trial conducted by Kubo et al [ 48] assessed the feasibility of a commercially available mindfulness program in which they targeted patients with cancer and their caregivers. This program leads to an increase in quality of life in patients with cancer with a medium effect size [ 48]. Similar to these findings, Rosen et al [ 49] reported that the quality of life of patients with breast cancer improved with a small effect size using a commercially available mindfulness course when compared with a control group. As depressive symptoms and anxiety were not significantly reduced in the total sample in our study, we also looked at subsamples with higher HADS scores. In the high anxiety and high depression subsamples, anxiety and depression, respectively, decreased significantly over time. This might indicate that a mindfulness and relaxation mHealth intervention is especially beneficial for patients with cancer with higher emotional distress. This is also in line with a study by Barth et al [50], where highly distressed patients benefited most from psycho-oncological interventions. However, we did not find any group effects when comparing continuous app users with intervention dropouts. This might indicate that our definition of users and dropouts is not precise enough or that another variable than time spent practicing is responsible for changes in outcomes. For adoption, our results showed that at week 20 of the intervention, 25 of 100 patients were using the app continuously. With 54 of 100 continuous app users at week 10 [ 36], this leads to a dropout rate of approximately 50% every 10 weeks. The 25 continuous app users practiced on average 3 to 5 times per week (median), which comes close to our initially statedrecommendation of 5 exercises per week. We consider this a good adoption of the mHealth intervention because the intervention was set up as a self-care intervention without the involvement of a therapist or health professional. Mindfulness was the preferred exercise, followed by guided imagery and progressive muscle relaxation. However, mindfulness meditation exercises were also presented as the first choice in the app, whereas guided imagery was placed at the second position, and progressive muscle relaxation was placed at the third position. Therefore, the preference for mindfulness meditation could also be caused by the placement of the exercises in the app. These results regarding adoption are comparable with those of a study conducted by Kubo et al [ 48], in which patients with cancer received access to the commercially available mindfulness app Headspace (TM). In this study, 40 of 54 patients with cancer allocated to the intervention group completed the 8-week study, and 20 patients with cancer used the app on at least 50% of the days [ 48]. The results from the interviews with health professionals provide some insights into the implementation of a mindfulness and relaxation mHealth intervention into standard care. In general, all interviewed health professionals perceived the app as a helpful addition to standard care. The health professionals also suggested some improvements, which might increase the acceptance and long-term use of such mHealth interventions by patients. A suggested improvement shared by all health professionals is the increase in the content of the app, such as additional exercises or variations of the exercises. A statement about the implementation of the mHealth intervention given by several health professionals was the adequate provision of information. One of the interviewed MBM psychologists as well as the nursing experts stated that patients with cancer are, on the one hand, flooded with information, especially when they start their treatment. However, the provision of some information to the patients about a mHealth intervention is necessary, at least to let the patients know about the existing intervention. On the other hand, nursing experts also mentioned that nurses often forgot about the intervention, although they approve this kind of intervention. Therefore, a standardized procedure for informing patients about the mHealth intervention might facilitate the implementation of the intervention. In addition, health professionals such as nurses might have to be informed regularly about such interventions because it is not part of their standard treatment; therefore, they might forget about it, as seen in this study. Regarding the recruitment process, the health professionals made the observation that female patients were more interested in this mHealth intervention. This is also reflected by the gender ratio in this study's sample, with 76 female and 24 male patients with cancer, which is typical for complementary and alternative treatments [ 51-53]. This gender difference raises the question of whether an effort should be made to better recruit male patients with cancer for such an intervention. A nursing expert, for instance, mentioned during the interview that a focus on more technical aspects or facts could be more appealing to male patients. Strengths, Limitations, and Future Directions This study has several strengths and limitations. A strength of the study is the collection of objective data in the form of JMIR Cancer 2021 | vol. 7 | iss. 1 | e16785 | p. 10 https://cancer.jmir.org/2021/1/e16785 (page number not for citation purposes)Mikolasek et al JMIR CANCER XSL·FO RenderX71logging the exercise use for each patient over the course of 20 weeks. Therefore, data on using the app exercises were not biased through self-report. Another advantage of this study was the use of a mixed methods approach, which is recommended for the development of digital interventions [ 54]. A limitation of the study is that we did not have a control group. Therefore, the effectiveness of the app cannot be determined in this study because regression to the mean could have an impact on the improvement of well-being. Furthermore, we used paper-and-pencil questionnaires, which might have led to more missing data compared with web-based questionnaires [ 55]. However, this was compensated by using LMM analyses, which take into account all patients who provided baseline data. Another limitation is that we did not assess whether patients were practicing mindfulness and relaxation exercises without the app, which could have an effect on the assessed outcomes. Therefore, future studies should investigate this topic with a randomized controlled trial to determine the effectiveness of a mindfulness and relaxation mHealth intervention. Our study provides some insights regarding the effects that might be expected in a similar study, which will be helpful to power future studies sufficiently. We also looked at aspects of implementing an mHealth intervention. All interviewed health professionals perceived such an mHealth intervention as ahelpful addition to standard care, but as described earlier, they also stated barriers to the implementation of such an intervention, which should be investigated in future studies. Future studies could also investigate an mHealth intervention with more content than in this study app, as suggested during the interviews by health professionals. For instance, audio files with background music or exercises with variations in their duration could be added. In addition to mindfulness and relaxation exercises, physical exercise programs could be added. Physical exercise can have beneficial effects on symptoms of patients with cancer [ 56], and physical exercise has already been implemented in mHealth apps for patients with cancer [57]. Conclusions The results of this observational feasibility study indicate that a mindfulness and relaxation app can be a feasible and an effective way to deliver a self-care intervention for patients with cancer. Our results indicate that such an intervention might be especially beneficial for highly distressed patients with cancer. The appeal of such an app could be increased with more diverse content, which might also positively affect the adherence of patients to such an intervention. The effectiveness and further aspects regarding the implementation of such an mHealth intervention should be investigated in a future randomized controlled trial. JMIR Cancer 2021 | vol. 7 | iss. 1 | e16785 | p. 14 https://cancer.jmir.org/2021/1/e16785 (page number not for citation purposes)Mikolasek et al JMIR CANCER XSL·FO RenderX7576 C.GENERAL DISCUSSION The first aim of the present PhD thesis was to summarize the effectiveness of mindfulness- and relaxation-based eHealth interventions for patients with medical conditions. This goal was tackled by summarizing results from empirical studies in a systematic review. A second aim of this PhD thesis was to evaluate the feasibility of a mindfulness- and relaxation app for cancer patients. For this purpose, we conducted a prospective observational study with cancer patients using an app to practice mindfulness and relaxation exercises. The results obtained in each study are discussed in detail in the included manuscripts. This section summarizes the key findings of every study and integrates our findings into the current research context, and highlights future directions for practice and research. 1. Summary of findings We first conducted a systematic review in which we summarized mindfulness- and relaxation-based eHealth interventions for patients with medical conditions and the interventions' effects on health. We carried out a comprehensive literature search and included all available studies that were published between 1990 and 2015. We found 17 studies that matched our inclusion criteria, namely mindfulness- and relaxation-based eHealth intervention for patients with medical conditions that were mainly technology delivered with pre- and post-assessment of a health outcome. Out of these studies, 11 used mindfulness, 6 relaxation, and 3 studies both intervention strategies. The interventions were delivered for patients with irritable bowel syndrome, chronic fatigue syndrome, cancer, chronic pain, surgery, and hypertension. All in all, the majority of studies assessing the respective outcomes reported positive effects on general health (physical functioning, disability, quality of life), as well as depression, anxiety, or self-efficacy, and pain. No studies reported positive effects on stress or mindfulness. After the systematic review, we conducted a prospective observational study, where we provided cancer patients a mindfulness- and relaxation-based mHealth app and we gathered date over the course of 20 weeks. In our study we used a mixed-methods design to evaluate the feasibility of our mHealth intervention and applied the RE-AIM evaluation framework. We presented the results for the dimensions reach, adoption, and maintenance in 77 our second paper and the results for the dimensions effectiveness and implementation in our third and final paper. For the dimension reach, we reported that we were able to screen 117 eligible cancer patients of which 100 returned the informed consent form and were included in the study. The mean age of all enrolled patients was 53 years and the majority were female (n=74). With 39 cases, the most common cancer diagnosis was breast cancer. The majority of patients had completed higher education: 41 patients completed secondary education and 33 patients had a university degree. Regarding their well-being, patients reported on average elevated levels of distress at baseline, whereas anxiety and depression scores were on average normal. Since we designed our study with an intervention group only, i.e. without a control group and randomization, we were not able to examine the effectiveness of our mHealth intervention. Instead, we reported effects for our predefined health-related outcomes by analyzing changes over time. Our analyses revealed that over the course of the 20 week mHealth intervention, anxiety, distress, fatigue, sleep disturbance, quality of life, and mindfulness improved significantly. We also analyzed effects in subsamples with high depression, anxiety, and distress values and in every subsample the according outcomes improved significantly. We did not find any significant changes in physical functioning, depression, ability to participate in social roles and activities, and fear of progression. For adoption, we looked at the number of app exercises completed per week as well as the number of continuous app users (at least weekly use of one or more app exercises) vs intervention dropouts. Overall, the average of completed app exercises per week was quite low with a median of 2 exercises at week one, which dropped to a median of 1 at week 5 and 0 at week 9. When we however made a distinction between continuous app users and intervention dropouts, the numbers looked much more favorable for continuous app users. Over the course of the first 10 weeks of the intervention, 54 patients used app exercises regularly up until week 10. These continuous app users completed on average (median) 4 exercises in week 1 and 2 exercises in week 10. We furthermore looked at the app usage over the course of the entire 20 week, where we identified 24 (24%) continuous app users. These patients used on average (median) 6 app exercises in week 1 and 4 app exercises in week 20. To evaluate the implementation of the mHealth intervention, we conducted interviews with 5 health professionals. All health professionals perceived the mHealth intervention as a helpful addition to standard care. Furthermore, the interviewed health professionals made suggestions to increase the acceptance and long-term use of the mHealth app, which can be of 78 help for the implementation. The health professionals suggested to add more content (e.g. additional exercises or variations of the exercises), as well as increasing the awareness of the app for patients and health experts. For the dimension maintenance, we looked at predictors for adherence. Our analyses revealed that being female, higher scores in openness to experience, resistance to change, and depression significantly predicted continuous app use over the course of 10 weeks. 79 2. Discussion and integration of findings 2.1 Dimension Reach The evaluation of the dimension reach (i.e. which and how many cancer patients participate in the study) revealed that the majority of patients who were interested in participating (n=117) also enrolled in the study (n=100). However, since we used a variety of recruitment strategies such as distribution of leaflets at hospitals and social media, we do not know how many cancer patients we had been able to inform about the study. Therefore, we could not make an estimate which percentage of cancer patients are potentially interested in such an intervention. Our evaluation showed furthermore that the majority of enrolled patients were female (74%). This is congruent with other e- or mHealth intervention. For instance, in an online interventions for cancer patients (Beatty et al., 2017), out of 191 participating patients 84% were female. Another study looked at user characteristics of a meditation app and i n this study with more than 10'000 users, 79.94% were female (Huberty et al., 2019). In a further study with an mHealth mindfulness intervention for cancer patients, out of 97 patients 69% were female (Kubo et al., 2019). Regarding age, patients in our study were on average (mean) 53.24 years old and their age ranged from 23 to 84 years. Other e- and mHealth studies also reported similar age means and large ranges. A study by Beatty and colleagues (2017) examined the uptake of an online intervention for cancer related distress and reported that the mean age was 56.32 years. A study by Kubo an colleagues (2019) investigated a mHealth mindfulness intervention for cancer patients, where the mean age of participating patient was 59.3 years. This is contrary to the concern, that an age-based digital divide (i.e. limited access to information and communication technologies by older adults) exists in mHealth (Fox & Connolly, 2018), which might impair access to such intervention for older patients. Regarding patients' education, the majority of enrolled patients completed some form of higher education, with 41% of patients who completed secondary education and 33% of patients who had a university degree. This is also in line with a study conducted by Loquai and colleagues (2017) in melanoma patients, where higher education was associated with the use of complementary and alternative medicine, which also includes relaxation and mindfulness meditation. Another smartphone-based mindfulness study similarly reported that 80 participants were predominantly well-educated, with 41.3% of a sample of 121 having a postgraduate-level education (Howells, Ivtzan, & Eiroa-Orosa, 2016). Baseline values of mental health related outcomes showed on the one hand that distress was on average high with a mean of 5.9, which is considered as clinically relevant (Jacobsen et al., 2005). On the other hand, depressive symptoms and anxiety was on average not elevated. However, subsample analyses revealed that a substantial proportion of our sample reported elevated anxiety (35%) and depressive symptoms (20%). These baseline values are similar to a study by Kubo and colleagues (2019), a mHealth mindfulness intervention for cancer patients, in which the authors also used the distress thermometer and Hospital Anxiety and Depression Scale. In this study, cancer patients reported on average a baseline distress of 4.9. Also similar to our study sample, anxiety was more prevalent than depressive symptoms. Another study investigating a mHealth physical activity intervention to increase quality of life and distress in cancer patients also applied the distress-thermometer (Mayer et al., 2018). In this study, cancer patients reported lower baseline distress with an average of 3.36 in the control group and 2.98 in the intervention group (Mayer et al., 2018). This might indicate that mindfulness- and relaxation- based interventions are appealing to distressed cancer patients. Overall, these findings indicate that age is not a barrier for the uptake of an mHealth intervention, as stated by some researchers (Byambasuren, Glasziou, 2020; Wildenbos, Jaspers, Schijven, & Dusseljee-Peute, 2019). Furthermore, patients participating in the study had on average elevated levels of distress, indicating that patients showing signs of clinically relevant distress are willing to participate in a mindfulness- and relaxation-based mHealth intervention. However, being male and having a lower education have been reported as a barriers for the uptake of e- and mHealth interventions, which is also in line with our findings. 2.2 Dimension Effectiveness Regarding the dimension effectiveness, we reported effects over time and found significant improvements in anxiety, distress, fatigue, sleep disturbance, quality of life, and mindfulness with small to medium effect sizes. Subsample analyses reveled significant improvements with large effects on distress in high distress subsample (62% of patients), anxiety in the high anxiety subsample (35% of patients), and depression in the high depression subsample (20% of patients). These findings are in line with other comparable 81 studies. A single group pilot study tested the feasibility of a mobile mindfulness-based stress reduction (mMBSR) for breast cancer program (Lengacher et al., 2018). Fifteen breast cancer survivors were recruited and all of them received access to a mMBSR program, which consisted of 6 weekly 2-hour sessions delivered through an iPad. After six weeks, cancer patients showed significant improvements in depression, anxiety, stress, fear of recurrence, sleep quality, fatigue, and quality of life with medium to large effect sizes. However, due to the small sample size and single group design, these preliminary result have to be interpreted with caution. Another study by Rosen and colleagues (2018) aimed to assess the efficacy of a commercially available mindfulness-app on quality of life in breast cancer patients. In this study, 112 cancer patients were randomized to the app intervention group or a waitlist control group. Analyses showed that cancer patients in the app intervention group reported higher quality of life as well as higher mindfulness scores from baseline through follow-up compared to the patients in the wait list control group. A further study assessed the feasibility of a mHealth mindfulness intervention for cancer patients (Kubo et al., 2019). Out of 97 patients, 52 were allocated to the intervention group and received access to the commercially available app Headspace for 8 weeks. Compared to the control group, patients in the intervention arm had significantly greater improvements in emotional well-being and overall well-being between baseline and post-intervention. To conclude, current research indicates that mindfulness- and relaxation based- intervention can have positive effects in cancer patients. However, only a few studies have been published in this field of research. Furthermore, some of these studies had small sample sizes and therefore low statistical power, which increases the likelihood of a type II error (failing to reject a false null hypothesis) and reduces the likelihood that a significant results reflects a true effect (Button et al., 2013). Furthermore, our study as well as other studies used a single group design. Due to the lack of a control group and random allocation, unambiguous inferences about the interventions' effectiveness cannot be made. Therefore, randomized controlled trials with large enough sample sized to achieve adequate power are needed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness- and relaxation-based mHealth interventions. 2.3 Dimension Adoption For the dimension adoption we looked at the adherence of cancer patients to the app intervention. Our results showed that on average the enrolled cancer patients did not adhere to our recommendation of conducting 5 exercises per week. During the first 4 weeks of the intervention, the enrolled patients completed on average 2 exercises per week and the average 82 completion of app exercises dropped to zero in week nine. However, since the range of completed exercises was large amongst the patients, we furthermore created user subgroups by classifying patients as continuous app users and intervention dropouts, who stopped using the app at some point during the intervention. Theses analyses revealed that over half of the patients used the app exercises regularly (at least one completed exercise per week) up until week 10. However, these continuous app users did not reach our recommended 5 exercises per week either, since these patients completed on average between 4 and 2 exercises per week. Looking at continuous app use until week 20, we were able to categorize a quarter of all enrolled cancer patients as continuous app users. Therefore, the number of patients who were committed to use the app regularly for the first 10 weeks was moderate and dropped further until week 20. However, patients still using the app in week 20 showed overall a good adherence to the app intervention, with the number of completed app exercises per week varying between 3 and 6 exercises. These numbers indicate that although the majority of patients stopped using the app after a while, with a quarter of all enrolled patients a considerable number of patients were using the app over a prolonged period. This is insofar promising, since our intervention did only involve minimal patient contact and a respectable number of patients therefore used the app self-reliantly according to our recommendations. Furthermore, once an app intervention is established, it can be distributed easily to a large part of a desired population. Comparing the adherence to other studies is restricted since different mindfulness- and relaxation-based mHealth interventions can vary substantially (e.g. varying intervention duration and complexity) and adherence is oftentimes defined differently. However, recent studies with comparable intervention strategies report promising results regarding patients' adherence to a mindfulness- or relaxation based-eHealth intervention. A randomized controlled trial by Beatty and colleagues (2017) investigated the uptake and adherence to a self-care CBT online intervention, aiming to reduce cancer-related distress. The intervention consisted of a 6-week internet application which was divided into 6 modules. These modules covered different topics such as coping with physical symptoms and emotional distress and included amongst others relaxation and meditation exercises (Beatty, Kemp, Wade, & Koczwara, 2015). The authors reported an acceptable adherence, with 60% of patients completing 4 or more modules and 40% completing all 6 modules (Beatty et al., 2017). Another randomized controlled trial by Kubo and colleagues (2019) also looked at the adherence to an mHealth mindfulness intervention for cancer patients, which aimed to reduce distress and improve quality of life. The intervention group received access to the 83 commercially available Headspace app for 8 weeks. Among the patients who completed the intervention, 50% practiced mindfulness with the app at least at 50% of the days and 32.5% of patients practiced at least at 70% of the days with the app. In summary, the results obtained from early eHealth studies, indicating that low adherence is an inherent problem in e- and mHealth interventions (G. Eysenbach, 2005; Kelders, Kok, Ossebaard, & Van Gemert-Pijnen, 2012) do not hold up in more recent research. Furthermore, our results indicate that further analyses with subgroups of users (e.g. continuous users and intervention dropouts) provide a more accurate and optimistic picture regarding the adherence to an mHealth intervention. We found in our study that adherence varies substantially between patients and only looking at mean scores of practicing time or number of exercises across the entire sample leads to a biased depiction of adherence. Our subsample analyses showed that although the majority of patients did not adhere to the intervention, a substantial proportion of patients used the app exercises regularly, even over a prolonged time of 20 weeks. 2.4 Dimension Implementation For the dimension implementation we interviewed health professionals who work with cancer patients and who were also involved in recruiting patients for our study. Overall, the interviewees perceived the app as an appealing and helpful complementary tool. The acceptance of a new mHealth intervention by health professionals is a relevant prerequisite for the implementation in a clinical setting. This is in line with the results from a study which investigated the prescription of mHealth apps in general practice, where on the one hand general practitioners stated that they need to be convinced of the benefits of mHealth apps in order to recommend them to patients and on the other hand patients stated that they rely on doctors recommendations (Byambasuren et al., 2020). Our interviewees mentioned another relevant factor, namely that recommending and explaining the app to patients did not result in a lot of additional work for them. The amount of additional work can play an important role in the implementation of a new mHealth intervention, since health professionals treating cancer patients have a high work load and therefore added burden during the recruitment process can negatively affect the enrollment of eligible patients (Gupta, Ocker, & Chow, 2020). The health professionals mentioned several aspects which they perceived to have an impact on the implementation of a mindfulness- and relaxation-based mHealth intervention. One issue raised was the right timing of recommending a mHealth intervention, since cancer 84 patients are flooded with information during their first consultation or entry into the hospital. Therefore, the additional information about the mHealth intervention might get forgotten amongst all the other information. Hence, it might be advisable to inform patients about the intervention outside regular consultation hours and instead use an additional visit for this purpose. Another aspect mentioned by nursing experts was that nurses themselves oftentimes forgot about the mHealth intervention since it is not part of their regular routine of care. Therefore, it might be helpful to implement guidelines when additional information about an mHealth intervention can be provided. In addition, awareness about the intervention could be increased amongst nurses for instance by mentioning such new complementary treatments during advanced trainings or during information events. In line with these suggestions, Gupta and colleagues (2020) stated that the coordination with clinical staff is an important factor influencing the implementation of mHealth interventions for cancer patients in a clinical setting. The authors highlighted the importance of understanding the work flow in a clinic and communication with key clinic staff for a successful recruitment of cancer patients (Gupta et al., 2020). Furthermore, the nursing experts in our study also mentioned that it might be helpful to have a dedicated mobile device where the app could be demonstrated. In addition, the provision of such a device might also help to remind the nurses about the existence of mHealth interventions. The interviewees also mentioned that adding more content to the app (e.g. more exercises) might increase the attractiveness of an mHealth intervention and therefore appeal to a larger number of patients. However, the ease of use of an mHealth app can also impact the acceptance of an app (Byambasuren et al., 2020) and a mHealth app that is perceived as too complex or difficult to use might be off-putting to patients and health professionals. Therefore, it has also been recommended to adapt a user-centered approach when developing a digital intervention, where stakeholder will be involved throughout the development process (Michie et al., 2017). With such an approach it seems more likely that a right balance between complexity or amount of content and usability will be reached. Another aspect that was mentioned in our interviews is that during the recruitment phase the health professionals observed that female patients were more interested in the mHealth intervention, which is congruent with the gender distribution in our study sample. As mentioned in the discussion regarding the dimension reach, this gender difference is also comparable to findings in other e- or m-Health studies with mindfulness and relaxation intervention strategies. To counter this gender bias during recruitment, a nursing expert mentioned in our interviews that maybe male patients could be motivated more to use a mindfulness- and relaxation-based mHealth intervention with slightly adapted recruitment strategies (e.g. focusing more on technical 85 aspects and facts while explaining the study to male patients). However, future studies will have to investigate if different recruitment strategies can lead to an increase of male participants and if so, which strategies are most promising. Another aspects with a potential impact on the implementation of a mHealth intervention which was not mentioned in our interviews but is discussed in other studies are privacy and data safety issues. However, results regarding privacy and data safety concerns so far are inconclusive (Byambasuren et al., 2020; del Río-Lanza, Suárez-Vázquez, Suárez-Álvarez, & Iglesias-Argüelles, 2020), requiring further research. To summarize, several aspects can influence the implementation of a mHealth intervention into standard care. Acceptance by health professionals and patients of an intervention are important aspects, as well as structural aspects like daily routine of health professionals. 2.5 Dimension Maintenance For the dimension maintenance we investigated potential predictors for continuous app use and during patient interviews we inquired possible reasons for continuous and discontinuous app use. Our analyses revealed that being female, higher scores in openness to experience as well as a higher resistance to change score, and higher depressive symptoms predicted continuous app use. Our interviews gave further insights about factors influencing the continuous use of the app. As reasons for a long-term use of the app exercises, continuous app users stated that they perceived the exercises as beneficial and that the exercises helped them to relax. Interviewed intervention dropouts mentioned various reason for a discontinued use of the app. Some patients stated that they had previous experience with relaxation or meditation exercises and that these routines differed from the ones in the app. These differences were perceived as distracting and the patients stated that they could not get used to the new instructions, which is why these patients stopped using the app. Other patients mentioned different distraction such as peculiar sounding instruction or fatigue, which led to a discontinued app use. One patient also mentioned technical problem with his smartphone, which prevented a continuous use of the app. These results indicate that for a prolonged use of a mindfulness- and relaxation-based app, a variety of different interindividual reasons can have an impact. Several distracting factors or different preferences for instance can lead to noncompliance to a specific app intervention. Therefore, setting up an app intervention with some variety might appeal to a larger number of patients. 86 So far, studies investigating possible predictors for continuous mHealth app use of cancer patients are sparse. Furthermore, these studies oftentimes investigate different potential predictors for continuous app use and use different definitions of app use, which impedes comparisons across studies as well as generalizing the results. A study by Psihogios and colleagues (2021) evaluated possible predictors for engagement (i.e. frequency of app use) with a self-care mHealth app for adolescent and young adult cancer survivors. This study investigated a variety of potential predictors: demographic variables (e.g. sex, age), disease factors (e.g. cancer type, cancer treatment), psychological factors (e.g. goal motivation, health beliefs) as well as other characteristics such as type of phone and time of year. Contrary to our findings, the authors of this study reported that lower depression predicted higher mHealth engagement (Psihogios et al., 2021). Apart from that, uninterrupted app access, iPhone (vs. Android-based smartphone) ownership, receiving the intervention in summer months predicted a higher app engagement (Psihogios et al., 2021). A systematic review examined the feasibility of mindfulness-based e- and mHealth interventions for cancer patients (Matis, Svetlak, Slezackova, Svoboda, & umec, 2020) and summarized - amongst others - predictors of adherence. In line with our study, a pilot study of a web-based mindfulness-based cognitive therapy intervention reported that being female was a predictor for continuous use of the program (Everts, Van Der Lee, & de Jager Meezenbroek, 2015). However, contrary to our results, in the study by Everts and colleagues (2015) lower depressive symptoms at baseline was associated with a continuous use of the online program. Other predictive factors for continuous program use were higher education, employment, and previous experience with mindfulness (Everts et al., 2015). Furthermore, some studies did not find any significant predictors for continuous program or app use (Matis et al., 2020). To conclude, some preliminary results regarding factors that contribute to continuous app use in mHealth intervention have been reported. However, current results are heterogenous and sometimes contradictory. Therefore, future studies will have to investigate in which situation contradicting results (e.g. depressive symptoms) are associated with continuous app use. In addition, due to the low number of studies, current consistent findings for continuous app use predictors (e.g. female sex) need to b e replicated and investigated in different setting. 87 3. Implications 3.1 Implications for Practice Our studies provide at least three main implications for practice. The first implication concerns the uptake of and adherence to an intervention, which are important prerequisites for effective health interventions. However, both factors have been reported as shortcomings in e- and mHealth interventions. Our research contributes to the current mHealth literature by indicating possible factors which can influence the uptake of and adherence to a mHealth intervention. These findings can help health professionals to identify suitable patients for an mHealth intervention. In regard to uptake of e- or mHealth interventions, early research indicated that age can be a potential barrier for the uptake of such interventions. Contrary to such previous findings, our research indicates that age is not a barrier for mHealth uptake, which is also congruent with other more recent research in this field. Since cancer patients' age varies considerably and cancer patients in all age groups report reduced well-being, it is important to reach all age groups with effective health care services. According to our findings, a mindfulness- and relaxation mHealth intervention is similarly appealing to different age groups and therefore, health professionals should not see age as a contraindication for recommending such an intervention to older patients. However, our results indicate that male sex and a lower education seem to be barriers for the uptake of a mindfulness- and relaxation-based mHealth intervention since more often females and patients with higher education participated in our study. This is also in line with research on psychosocial interventions as well as complementary medicine, which shows that women are more likely to use such interventions. Furthermore, our results also indicate that female patients are more adherent to a mindfulness- and relaxation mHealth intervention. These results can help health professionals to identify patients who are more likely to use a mindfulness and relaxation mHealth in the long run. In turn, these results can also be helpful to identify patients who are more likely to stop using an app and therefore might require a health professional to continuously motivate the patient. A second implication of our research is that more features in an app can potentially increase its appeal to a larger number of patients, which might also positively effect uptake of and adherence to an mHealth intervention. However, the balance between the quantity and complexity of features and the easiness to use has to be considered during the app development. 88 Our results showed that patients had in general a positive impression about the mindfulness- and relaxation-based app developed for our study. Some patients who disliked the app and stopped using it mentioned factors such as dislikable language during the exercises or lack of variety of exercises, which lead them to cease using the app. For a better adherence, more features could be implemented in a mHealth apps to satisfy different needs across potential users. One problem however with additional features will be the increasing complexity of the app, which can decrease the ease of use and therefore impede the development of an acc essible design (Azhar & Dhillon, 2016; Pach, Rogge, Wang, & Witt, 2021) . Therefore, upcoming apps will have to achieve a balance between a large as possible appeal by the implementation of more features while still maintaining an acceptable usability of the app. A third implication of our research is that for a better implementation of a new mHealth intervention, health professionals' awareness of the intervention needs to be increased, for instance during advanced trainings or team meetings. Our results indicated that the interviewed health professionals had in general a positive impression of the app and perceived it as a helpful tool for their patients. Interestingly, although health professional rated the app favorably, only a few were able to recommend the app to patients. Our inquires in the interviews showed that nurses faced difficulties to recommend the app due to time constraints and the large amount of information they already need to provide to patients about their regular treatment. In addition to that it also became apparent during our interviews that health professionals oftentimes are in situation where they would like to have access to a tool like our app, which they could recommend to patients with elevated levels of distress. However, since the app was a new and unfamiliar tool, some health professionals oftentimes forgot to recommend the app in suitable situations. Therefore, for an adequate implementation of a new mHealth intervention it seems necessary to adequately inform stakeholders in healthcare (e.g. nurses) about existing mHealth app. In addition, implementing guidelines about the provision of information regarding mHealth interventions could also help to disseminate such an app because simply informing health professionals about the existence of a new intervention will most likely lead to a small impact, which became apparent in our study. 3.2 Implications for Research Since we did not conduct a randomized controlled trial, we were not able to make any inferences about the effectiveness of our mHealth intervention. Therefore, additional randomized controlled trials are needed to determine the effectiveness of mindfulness- and relaxation-based mHealth interventions. However, our results showed positive pre-post effects 89 in different health-related domains and the reported effect sizes can help future trials to adequately power the study. Currently, as a follow-up to our feasibility study a multicenter RCT is being set up (funded by the Swiss Cancer League). This upcoming study aims to determine the effectiveness of a mindfulness- and relaxation app for patients with elevated levels of distress by comparing the intervention group to a waitlist group. Since effectiveness studies investigate an intervention in normal clinical conditions, a challenge will be addressing potential confounding variables such as cointerventions and comorbidities of patients. Future research should also look in more detail into predictors for adherence, which will be helpful to identify suitable patients for a mindfulness- and relaxation-based mHealth intervention. Sub-sample analyses of our data (Siebenhüner, Mikolasek, Witt, & Barth, 2021) for instance showed that patients' level of distress might have an impact on adherence. These results showed that a decrease in patients' distress was associated with lower adherence, whereas patients with moderate distress as well as patients with an increase in destress over time adhered better to the intervention. However, a current problem in mHealth adherence research lies in different reporting of adherence across studies, which reduces generalizability and comparability of results. A standardized reporting of adherence across mHealth interventions is hardly possible, since interventions vary sometimes substantially in their characteristics (e.g. duration of the intervention and exercises, number of exercises or modules). Future research should therefore aim to report clearly their assessment of adherence assessments, with as many data as available (e.g. completed exercises or modules, time spent with the app. Finally, a common problem with current mHealth research is the knowledge transfer from research into clinical practice. Currently, a lot of commercial apps are available on the market with little scientific support (Lau et al., 2020). However, evidence-based research apps are only available for a limited time (i.e. study duration) and access is oftentimes restricted to study participants. A possible way to tackle this problem is currently implemented in Germany by the Federal Institute for Drugs and Medical Devices (Bundesinstitut für Arzneimittel und Medizinprodukte; BfArM). The BfArM established an application procedure in which medical devices, such as mHealth apps, can be submitted for the inclusion in the directory of reimbursable medical devices. Following a submission, the BfArM will assess several product qualities (e.g. data protection, user friendliness, effectiveness). If the requirements are met, the medical device will be listed in the directory of reimbursable medical devices. These medical devices then can be prescribed by physicians and psychotherapists as part of the treatment, 90 whereby the cost of the medical device will be covered by the health insurance (Federal Institute for Drugs and Medical Devices, 2021). Such a procedure can potentially help in making evidence-based apps accessible to the general population and therefore could be an example for other countries as well. 4. Strengths and limitations This thesis has several strengths and limitations. We first conducted a systematic review, which is a good way to summarize the current evidence in the field of interest. A strength of our systematic review was the extensive literature search in several databases. Another strength was the development of a standardized manual for data extraction, which was done by two reviewers independently. However, since we included studies with different mindfulness- and relaxation-based intervention strategies for a variety of medical conditions, we were not able to perform a meta-analysis. Therefore, our systematic review provides a narrative synthesis of the literature, but due to the lack of a meta-analysis, a statistical estimate of effectiveness could not be reported. Another limitation of our systematic review was that mindfulness or relaxation can be one out of several treatment strategies in a complex intervention, which can impede comparisons between different studies. We therefore defined as an inclusion criteria that the ratio of mindfulness or relaxation treatment strategies to the total number of intervention strategies had to be at least 1 to 5. Therefore, studies might have been excluded from our systematic review, if an intervention had a multitude of different intervention strategies besides mindfulness or relaxation. This is also highlighted by a comparison of our work with a systematic review (Spijkerman, Pots, & Bohlmeijer, 2016) that summarized mindfulness-based interventions for improving mental health. In this work by Spijkerman and colleagues (2016), three studies were included which used online acceptance and commitment therapy interventions that also included mindfulness exercises. Because of our above-mentioned inclusion criteria, we did not include these studies, which illustrates that depending on the set criteria for inclusion, the study selection can differ. Another general limitation of systematic reviews is that by time of publication, new studies have most likely emerged, which are not included in the review. This seems especially true in fields like e- and mHealth, where a lot of studies were done in the last couple of years. The mHealth study that we conducted afterwards has also some strengths and limitations. A strength of our study was that we collected objective data for app use, namely through logging the exercises use for each patient. This method of data collection overcomes possible biases 91 that can occur in self-reports and is very precise, since the exact practice time is logged. Another strength of our study was the applied mixed-methods approach, which has been recommended for the development and evaluation of digital interventions (Michie et al., 2017). We assessed a variety of quantitative data (i.e. health-related outcomes and data on app use) and we conducted qualitative interviews with patients as well as health professionals. This mixed- methods approach allowed us to assess the feasibility of our mHealth study more diversely. Finally, we conducted an intervention with a duration of 20 weeks, which provides a more conclusive picture about the adoption of the intervention compared to shorter studies. Our mHealth study had also several limitations. First, for the evaluation of the intervention adoption, we had to define continuous app users and app non-users. Since we did not have any empirical data regarding a clinically impactful dose of such an mHealth intervention, we defined a continuous app user as a patient, who used at least one app exercise per week. Second, we did not conduct a randomized controlled trial, since we were uncertain if we would be able to recruit enough patients for an adequately powered study. Therefore, we were only able to report within group changes over time for our outcomes of interest. Although these analyses provide information about possible effect, estimates about the effectiveness of the intervention could not be provided. Third, we did not assess if cancer patients were practicing mindfulness or relaxation exercises outside the app or if they did yoga etc., which might be an important confounding variable. 92 5. Conclusions A large body of research shows that a cancer diagnosis, its' treatment and recovery oftentimes lead to considerable amount of psychological distress and reduced quality of life. Although this is recognized and increasing cancer patients' quality of life is an additional desired outcome in cancer patients' treatment, health professionals and patients are confronted with several barriers. To overcome such barriers (e.g. geographical distance to treatment providers, lack of adequate treatments) e- and mHealth interventions have been suggested. The present work makes a valuable contribution in this field of research by summarizing the effectiveness of relaxation-based eHealth interventions and evaluating the feasibility of a mindfulness- and relaxation-based mHealth app for cancer patients. In our systematic review we concluded that relaxation-based eHealth interventions can be effective in increasing patients' quality of life. However, at the time we conducted the literature search, we did not find any mHealth studies. Therefore, our subsequent mHealth feasibility study contributed to close this gap. In our study, cancer patients received access to a mindfulness- and relaxation-based mHealth intervention. Our results showed that adoption of the intervention was acceptable and a substantial number of patients used the mHealth interventions over a prolonged period of time. Preliminary results also showed that such an intervention can have positive effects on a variety of health outcomes. Furthermore, patients as well as health professionals rated the app favorably but also gave insightful suggestions for improvement. To conclude, the results of this dissertation demonstrate that a mindfulness- and relaxation-based mHealth app can be a feasible way to deliver those interventions for cancer patients with the aim to increase their quality of life. Since we used a single group design in our study, the effectiveness of mindfulness-and relaxation-based mHealth studies needs to be addressed in future RCTs. Furthermore, we looked at possible predictors for adherence. However, current research regarding predictors for adherence in mHealth interventions is inconclusive. Since adherence is an important prerequisite for an effective intervention, future studies should therefore evaluate this in more detail. 93 References Aboumrad, M., Shiner, B., Riblet, N., Mills, P.
